PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of St. Clair, Michigan. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1975 Code, as supplemented through December 17, 1990, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1975 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 4 is 4-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 3-1 and 3-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 3-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix.

Indexes 
    The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Allen Z. Paul, Supervising Editor, and Charles Vignos, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Janice DiGiusto, City Clerk, for her cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that her efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION

ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 1994-03 
CITY OF ST. CLAIR 
COUNTY OF ST. CLAIR, MICHIGAN 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE CITY OF ST. CLAIR; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
The City of St. Clair Ordains: 
    Section 1. The Code entitled "St. Clair City Code of Ordinances" published by Municipal Code Corporation consisting of Chapters 1 through 70, each inclusive, and appendix A, is adopted. 
    Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before December 20, 1993, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or by imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or both fine and imprisonment. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided shall apply to the amendment of any Code section whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in the form as to intention of the city council to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 6. Ordinances adopted after December 20, 1993 that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    Section 7. This ordinance shall become effective July 26, 1994. 
    Passed and adopted by the city council this Fifth day of July, 1994. 
ORDINANCE DECLARED ADOPTED

PART I - CHARTER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein is the St. Clair City Charter, as adopted by the electors on August 7, 1979, and effective on January 1, 1980. Amendments to the Charter are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original Charter. Obvious misspellings have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, a uniform system of headings, catchlines and citations to state statutes has been used. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets. 

ARTICLE 1. - INCORPORATION, BOUNDARY AND POWERS 

Section 1.01. - Incorporation. 
    The existing and established City of St. Clair in the County of St. Clair, State of Michigan, shall be a home rule municipal corporation under the provisions of Act No. 279 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1909 (MCL 117.1 et seq., MSA 5.2071 et seq.) as now, or hereafter, amended and as declared by Act No. 334 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1976 (MCL 81.1c, MSA 5.1591(3)). 
Section 1.02. - Boundaries. 
    The boundaries of the City of St. Clair are established to be: 
    The City of St. Clair lying adjacent to and westerly of the international boundary line in the St. Clair River, being part of Fractional Sections 29 and 30, Township 5 North, Range 17 East, and P.C.'s 304, 305 and 306, St. Clair County, Michigan, being more particularly described as beginning at the east quarter corner of Fractional Section 30; thence westerly along the east and west quarter line of said Section 30 to the west line of said Section 30, said west line also being the centerline of Range Road; thence southerly along the said west line to the centerline of Brown Street, said centerline also being the northerly line of P.C. 305; thence westerly on the said northerly line to the northwest corner of P.C. 305; thence southerly along the westerly line of P.C. 305 to the southwest corner of P.C. 305, said corner being on the centerline of Cox Road, 66 feet wide, 209.60 feet northerly of the centerline of Clinton Avenue, said point being also on the northerly line of P.C. 306; thence westerly on the northerly line of P.C. 306 to the northwest corner of P.C. 306; thence southerly along the west line of P.C. 306 to the centerline of the Pine River; thence southerly and easterly along the centerline of the Pine River to the intersection of said centerline with the easterly line of P.C. 306, said easterly line being also the westerly line of P.C. 304; thence northerly along said line to the southerly line of Outlot No. 13 of the map of P.C.'s 304 and 305 as recorded in Liber D, Page 36, St. Clair County Records; thence easterly along said southerly line to the centerline of the Pine River; thence southerly along said centerline to a point, said point being on a line 44 feet south of the north line of Oak Street extended westerly to the centerline of said Pine River; thence easterly along said line to the westerly shore line of the St. Clair River; thence easterly at the right angles to the thread of the river to the international boundary line; thence northerly along the international boundary line to its intersection with a line which begins on the west shore line of the St. Clair River and its intersection with the east and west quarter line of Fractional Section 29 and runs thence easterly and at the right angles to the thread of the river to the international boundary line; thence westerly on said line to the west shore line; thence westerly along the said east and west quarter line of Fractional Section 29 to the Point of Beginning; 
and shall include any and all territory which may thereafter be annexed or attached thereto. 
State Law reference- Incorporation, consolidation of territory and alteration of boundaries of home rule cities, MCL 117.61 et seq., MSA 5.2085 et seq. 
Section 1.03. - Powers [generally]. 
    The city shall possess and have any and all powers which are possible for a city to possess and have under the constitution and laws of the State of Michigan as fully and completely as though they were specifically enumerated. In all instances such powers shall be liberally construed in favor of the city. Whenever specific powers may be set forth in the Charter, it shall not be interpreted as limiting in any way the broad grant of general power herein. 
State Law reference- Permissible that Charter provide that the city may exercise all municipal powers in the management and control of municipal property and in the administration of the municipal government, MCL 117.4j(3), MSA 5.2083(3). 
Section 1.04. - Exercise of [powers]. 
    The city may exercise any of its powers independently or in joint or common participation with any other municipal, governmental or private persons, bodies or organizations where authorized by law. 
ARTICLE 2. - CITY COUNCIL 

Section 2.01. - Composition, eligibility, election and terms. 
(a)  Composition. There shall be a city council consisting of the mayor and six (6) councilmembers elected by the registered voters of the city. 
(b)  Eligibility. Only registered voters of the city shall be eligible to be a candidate for and hold the office of councilmember. 
(c)  Wards. The city shall be divided into three (3) wards which shall be apportioned as near equally as possible by population. The council shall reapportion the wards within seventy-five (75) days following each official state or federal census. 
(d)  Election and terms. There shall be two (2) councilmembers elected by the registered voters in each ward for a term of two (2) years at the regular election held in odd-numbered years as prescribed by state law and in the manner as prescribed in Article 9 of this Charter. 
State Law reference- Mandatory that Charter provide for one or more wards, MCL 117.3(e), MSA 5.2073(e). 
Section 2.02. - The mayor. 
(a)  Election. The chief executive officer of the city shall be the mayor who shall be elected by the registered voters of the city at large for a term of two (2) years at a regular election held in an odd-numbered year as prescribed by state law and in the manner as prescribed in Article 9. The mayor shall preside at meetings of the council, shall be recognized as the head of the city government for all ceremonial purposes and by the governor for the purposes of military law, but shall have no administrative duties. 
(b)  Member of council. The mayor shall have an equal voice and vote as a member in all proceedings of the council, but shall have no veto power. 
(c)  Eligibility. Only registered voters of the city shall be eligible to be a candidate for and hold the office of mayor. 
(d)  Pro tempore. At the first regular meeting of the new council elected following the odd-year election, the council shall select from among its members the mayor pro tempore who shall act during the absence, disability or unavailability of the mayor, and, if a vacancy occurs, shall become mayor for the remainder of the term. 
Section 2.03. - Compensation and expenses. 
(a)  Compensation. The council shall determine the compensation of the mayor and councilmembers by ordinance, but no ordinance increasing such compensation shall become effective until the beginning date of the term of any councilmember elected or appointed thereafter; provided, such election or appointment follows the adoption of such ordinance by not less than six (6) months. 
(b)  Expenses. The mayor and councilmembers shall receive all actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties of office. Appropriate verification of the amount and purpose of such expenses shall be required by the city council. 
State Law reference- Mandatory that Charter provide for compensation of officers, MCL 117.3(d), MSA 5.2073(d). 
Section 2.04. - General powers and duties. 
    All powers of the city shall be vested in the council except when otherwise provided by law or the Charter. The council shall provide for the exercise of its powers and for the performance of all duties and obligations imposed on the city by law or this Charter. 
Section 2.05. - Judge of qualifications. 
    The council shall be the judge of the election qualifications of its members and of the grounds for forfeiture of their offices, and for that purpose shall have power to subpoena witnesses, administer oaths and require the production of evidence. Those charged with conduct constituting grounds for forfeiture of their offices shall be entitled to a public hearing on demand. Notice of such hearing shall be published in one or more newspapers of general circulation in the city at least one (1) week in advance of the hearing. Decisions made by the council under this section shall be subject to enforcement by the courts in an action of quo warranto. 
Section 2.06. - Procedure. 
(a)  Meetings. 
(1)  The council shall meet regularly at least twice in every month at such times and places as the council may prescribe by resolution. 
(2)  Special meetings shall be called by the clerk on the written request of the mayor or four (4) or more members of the council. Notice of such special meetings with the stated purpose therefor in writing designating the time and place thereof shall be delivered personally to each member or left at his usual place of residence within such time as shall be established by state law but in no event less than twenty-four (24) hours. No action shall be taken at any special meeting unless the same shall have been clearly listed in the purpose of the notice of the special meeting. Notices shall be visibly posted on the front door of the city hall. 
(3)  The public in attendance shall have a right to be heard during council meetings prior to a vote by the council. The council may require each person to identify him or her self by name and address and may prescribe rules for the reasonable exercise of this right. 
(b)  Rules and procedure. The council shall determine its own rules and order of business and shall provide for keeping a journal of every meeting of the council. 
(c)  Voting and quorum. Voting, except on procedural motions, shall be by roll call and the "ayes" and "nays" shall be recorded in the journal. Four (4) members of the council shall constitute a quorum. 
(d)  Publications or proceedings. Within five (5) days after each meeting of the council, the minutes or a synopsis thereof of the proceedings of the city council shall be prepared by the city clerk and approved by the mayor and shall be posted at city hall, and published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city prior to the next regular meeting of the council. 
(e)  Conflict of interest. No councilmember shall vote on any question a) involving that member's claimed misconduct; [or] b) where there exists a conflict of interest as provided by state law. 
State Law reference- Mandatory that Charter provide for public meetings, MCL 117.3(l), MSA 5.2073(l). 
Section 2.07. - Investigations. 
    The council may make investigations into the affairs of the city and the conduct of any city department, office or agency and for this purpose may subpoena witnesses, administer oaths, take testimony and require the production of evidence. Any person who fails or refuses to obey a lawful order issued in the exercise of these powers by the council shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or both. 
Section 2.08. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  Holding other city employment. Except where authorized by law, no member of council shall be employed by the city or hold any other city office during the term for which he is elected to the council. No former member of the council shall be employed by the city until one (1) year after the expiration of the term for which he was elected to the council. 
(b)  Appointments and removals. Neither the council nor any of its members shall in any manner dictate the appointment or removal of any city administrative officers or employees whom the city superintendent is empowered to appoint. The council may express its views and fully and freely discuss with the city superintendent anything pertaining to appointment and removal of such officers and employees. 
(c)  Interference with administration. The council or its members shall not deal with city officers and employees who are subject to the direction and supervision of the city superintendent except through the city superintendent, and neither the council nor its members shall give orders to any such officer or employee. 
(d)  Powers and duties of city superintendent. The council shall not diminish the duties and/or responsibilities of the office of the city superintendent as prescribed by this Charter, or by the ordinances required for implementation of this Charter. 
Section 2.09. - Vacancies and forfeitures. 
(a)  Vacancies. The office of councilmember shall be vacant upon the death, resignation, removal from office in any manner authorized by law, or forfeiture of the office. 
(b)  Forfeiture of office. Forfeiture of the office shall occur if a councilmember: 
(1)  Lacks at any time during the term of office any qualification for the office prescribed by this Charter or by state law; 
(2)  Violates any provision of this Charter; 
(3)  Is convicted of a felony; [or] 
(4)  Fails to attend three (3) consecutive regular meetings of the council without being excused by the council. 
(c)  Filling vacancies. A vacancy in the office of councilmember shall be filled by appointment by majority vote of the council within thirty (30) days of the time the vacancy occurs. The person appointed must possess all of the qualifications required of candidates for that office. The appointment shall be effective until the next regular odd-year election only, at which time a candidate shall be elected for the balance of any unexpired term remaining or for a full new term as the case may require. 
Section 2.10. - Independent audit. 
    The council shall provide for an annual certified audit of all city funds to be made by an independent certified public accountant selected by them who has no personal interest, direct or indirect, in the fiscal affairs of the city government. The council in its discretion may order such audits at more frequent periods whenever deemed necessary by a vote of five-sevenths ( 5/7 ) of the council. 
ARTICLE 3. - CITY SUPERINTENDENT 

Section 3.01. - Appointment, qualifications and compensation. 
    The council shall appoint a city superintendent for an indefinite term and establish the compensation. The superintendent shall be appointed solely on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications with special reference to training and actual experience in municipal administration. The superintendent need not be a resident of the city or state at the time of appointment, but shall be required to become a resident of the city within such period of time established by the city council unless this requirement is specifically waived by them. 
Section 3.02. - Acting city superintendent. 
    The council shall designate a qualified city administrative officer to exercise the powers and perform the duties of city superintendent during the temporary absence or disability of the city superintendent. 
Section 3.03. - Powers and duties. 
    The city superintendent shall be the chief administrative officer of the city and shall report to the mayor on administrative detail but shall be responsible to the mayor and council for the administration of all city affairs and administrative policy provided under this Charter or established by ordinance or resolution of the city council. The city superintendent shall: 
(a)  Have all supervisory control over all municipal employees and have such appointive and other authority over city administrative officers as provided by this Charter or ordinance or resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Direct and supervise the administration of all departments, offices and agencies of the city except as otherwise provided by this Charter or by laws of the state. The city superintendent may serve as the head of any department when so designated by the city council. 
(c)  Attend all council meetings and shall have the right to participate in council discussion but shall not have any vote. 
(d)  See that all laws, provisions of this Charter and actions of the council subject to enforcement by the city superintendent or by officers subject to his direction and supervision are faithfully executed. 
(e)  Prepare and submit the annual budget and capital program to the council. 
(f)  Submit to the council and make available to the public a complete report of the finances and administrative activities of the city as of the end of each fiscal year. 
(g)  Make such other reports as the council may require concerning the operation of city departments, offices and agencies subject to the city superintendent's direction and supervision. 
(h)  Keep the council fully advised as to the status of the current budget, the overall financial condition and the future needs of the city and make such recommendations to the council concerning the affairs of the city as he deems desirable or necessary. 
(i)  Administer the personnel and employee relation functions of the city and maintain all personnel records of city employees. 
(j)  Administer the purchasing function subject to provisions of this Charter and the procedures therefor established by the city council. 
(k)  Perform such other duties as are specified in this Charter or may be required and established by action of the city council. 
Section 3.04. - Removal from office. 
    The council may remove the superintendent from office in accordance with the following procedure: 
(a)  Council shall adopt by affirmative vote of a majority of all its members a preliminary resolution which must state the reasons for removal and may suspend the superintendent from duty for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days. A copy of the resolution shall be delivered to the superintendent within twenty-four (24) hours of its adoption. 
(b)  Within five (5) days after a copy of the resolution is delivered, the superintendent may file with the council a written request for a public hearing. This hearing shall be held at a council meeting not sooner than ten (10) days nor later than twenty-one (21) days after the request is filed. The superintendent shall file with the council a written reply to the charges not later than five (5) days before the hearing. 
(c)  Council may adopt the final resolution of removal which may be made effective immediately by affirmative vote of a majority of all its members at any time after five (5) days from the date when a copy of the preliminary resolution was delivered, if the superintendent has not requested a public hearing, or at any time after the public hearing in the case where one has been requested. The superintendent shall continue to receive salary until the effective date of a final resolution of removal or as otherwise required by contract. The action of the council in suspending or removing the superintendent shall not be subject to review by any court or other governmental agency. 
ARTICLE 4. - ADMINISTRATION 

Section 4.01. - Administrative departments. 
    The administrative functions of the city shall be assigned to departments of the city attorney, clerk, treasurer, assessor, fire, police, public works, sewer, water, parks and grounds, recreation, and inspection. The city council may by ordinance from time to time create, divide or combine departments whether authorized by this Charter or by ordinance in any manner it deems advisable or necessary for the proper and efficient operation of the city; provided, however, the council may not diminish the duties or responsibilities of the city superintendent by such addition, division or combination. 
Section 4.02. - Appointment of department heads. 
(a)  The city superintendent shall have the power to appoint or remove any administrative department head of the city with the advice and consent of the city council; provided, however, the city attorney shall be appointed or removed by the city council only. 
(b)  The city superintendent shall have the power to appoint and to remove subordinate employees of administrative departments and officers or delegate such power to the head of the particular department or office responsible for the purpose of making such appointments or removals within that department or office. 
(c)  All appointments shall be made solely on the basis of the fitness, training and experience of each candidate for appointment compared to the work expected to be performed. 
Section 4.03. - Duties. 
    All administrative officers and employees of the city shall perform the duties established for such officers or employees either by law, this Charter, the city ordinances or the lawful directives of the city superintendent. 
Section 4.04. - Compensation. 
    Compensation of all administrative officers and employees of the city shall be established and paid in accordance with city council budget appropriations and/or in compliance with the judgments, orders and directives of courts, tribunals and agencies of competent jurisdiction. 
Section 4.05. - City attorney. 
(a)  The legal officer of the city shall be the city attorney who shall be appointed for an indefinite term by the city council. The city attorney shall represent the city in all legal proceedings and shall serve as the legal advisor to the council and city superintendent. He shall perform such other duties as may be assigned by the city council or the city superintendent from time to time. 
(b)  The city council may appoint a special attorney whenever it shall appear necessary, or when recommended by the city attorney. 
Section 4.06. - Administrative agent. 
(a)  The city superintendent shall be the administrative agent of the council and shall be vested with all administrative powers of the city except as otherwise provided by this Charter and shall perform the duties of that office under the authority of, and be responsible to, the city council. Unless otherwise provided by Charter or required by law, all administrative officers and employees other than the city attorney shall be responsible to the city superintendent for the performance of their duties. 
(b)  The city superintendent shall supervise the performance of employees of all city boards and commissions in accordance with provisions of the Charter, ordinances establishing, and the directives of such boards and commissions. 
Section 4.07. - Boards and commissions. 
(a)  Boards and commissions may be established for the city by ordinance of the city council. They shall exercise such authority and perform such duties as may be granted to them and shall be subject to the provisions of the ordinance of their creation unless otherwise provided in this Charter or the state law. 
(b)  All members of boards and commissions shall be resident electors appointed by the city council for the prescribed term of office. Such residency requirements may be waived by a majority vote of the city council. Any member of the council, employee of the city or officer of the city may serve on a board or commission; provided, however, that no member of the city council shall serve on the zoning board of appeals. They may be removed from office for cause by the city council who shall be the sole judge of the adequacy of their performances. Such members sought to be removed shall be entitled to a written statement of the charges and to a public hearing based thereon before such removal shall occur. 
(c)  The mayor shall make the appointments with the advice and consent of the council and the council shall attempt to provide for an equal staggering of the terms of office for all members of each board and commission. 
(d)  Each board or commission shall have the authority to organize itself for the conduct of its business including the selection of officers. All rules of procedure shall be adopted after a public hearing. Such rules shall provide for notice in compliance with state law. 
(e)  The city council shall provide annual appropriations for the reasonable and necessary expenses of such boards and commissions to enable them to conduct their business. 
Section 4.08. - Implementation by ordinances. 
    The city council first elected after the effective date of this Charter shall, as soon as possible but not later than one year thereafter, by ordinance, adopt an administrative code which shall contain the specific powers, duties and responsibilities of each administrative department and the voluntary associations directly connected with the city. The administrative code shall also contain a schedule of rights and benefits of city employees. Where such rights or benefits are the subject of and set forth in a labor relations contract which has been negotiated with a collective bargaining unit on behalf of certain city employees, such contract shall control as to the employees in that unit. 
Section 4.09. - Annual reports. 
    All city officers, department heads, boards, commissions and voluntary associations shall at the time for submission of their proposed budget requirements for the coming fiscal year, as provided by Section 6.02, also submit a complete report of their administrative activities for the current fiscal year and the program of activities for the coming fiscal year. 
ARTICLE 5. - LEGISLATION 

Section 5.01. - Legislative power. 
    The legislative power of the city is exclusively vested in the council. All official action of the council shall be by ordinance or resolution, duly adopted by the affirmative vote of four (4) councilmembers. The council shall provide for the public peace, health, safety and the general welfare of persons and property within the city. 
State Law reference- Mandatory that Charter provide for body vested with legislative power, MCL 117.3(a), MSA 5.2073(a). 
Section 5.02. - Introduction of ordinances. 
    Every proposed ordinance shall be introduced in writing. 
Section 5.03. - Identification of ordinances. 
    Each ordinance shall be identified by a number and a short title. The enacting clause of every ordinance shall be "The City of St. Clair ordains." 
Section 5.04. - Time of enactment. 
    At least two (2) weeks shall elapse between the introduction and the enactment of an ordinance. 
Section 5.05. - Changes. 
    No ordinance shall be revised, altered or amended by reference to its title only, but the section or sections of the ordinance revised, altered or amended shall be reenacted and published at length, except where otherwise provided by law. 
Section 5.06. - Repeal. 
    An ordinance which repeals an existing ordinance may state the number, title and a brief description of the ordinance without stating the text of the ordinance being repealed. 
Section 5.07. - Recording. 
    The mayor and city clerk shall authenticate by signature and record all ordinances and resolutions in a properly indexed book kept for that purpose. However, the failure of the mayor and/or city clerk so to do shall not invalidate or suspend the operation of such ordinance or resolution. 
Section 5.08. - Publication. 
    After enactment of any ordinance, or a resolution having the effect of a law, the city clerk shall have it published as soon as possible, but not later than twenty-one (21) days after enactment, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
State Law reference- Mandatory that Charter provide for publication of all ordinances before they become operative, MCL 117.3(k), MSA 5.2073(k). 
Section 5.09. - Effective date. 
    The time when any ordinance shall take effect shall be prescribed therein. Such time, when the ordinance imposes a penalty, shall not be less than twenty-one (21) days from the day of its passage. 
Section 5.10. - Emergency ordinances. 
(a)  Emergency power. Emergency ordinances may be enacted to meet a public emergency affecting life, health, property or the public peace; provided, however, an emergency ordinance may not levy taxes, grant, renew or extend a franchise, or regulate the rates charged by any public utility for its services. 
(b)  Introduction requirements. An emergency ordinance shall be introduced in the form and manner required for ordinances generally, except that it shall contain, after the enacting clause, a declaration stating that an emergency exists and describing it in clear and specific terms. 
(c)  Adoption and effect of. An emergency ordinance may be adopted at a meeting at which it is introduced and given immediate effect. 
Section 5.11. - Adoption of codes by reference. 
    The council may adopt as an ordinance, by reference thereto without republication in whole or in part, the provisions of: 
(a)  Any Michigan statute; or 
(b)  Any detailed technical rules or regulations promulgated or enacted by: 
(1)  Any state or federal agency; 
(2)  A code of any organization or association which is organized and conducted for the purpose of developing such codes. The code shall be clearly identified in the ordinance which shall be published and shall contain a notice stating its purpose and that a complete copy of the code is available to the public at the office of the city clerk where printed copies of the code shall be available for inspection by and distribution to the public at all times. 
Section 5.12. - Codification. 
    All ordinances of the city shall be codified and identified as the St. Clair City Code of Ordinances. Copies [of the Code] shall be furnished to the city officers, placed in libraries and public offices for free public reference, and made available for purchase by the public at a reasonable price fixed by the city council. 
Section 5.13. - Prior city ordinances and official acts. 
    All ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations of the City of St. Clair which are not inconsistent with this Charter, and which are in force and in effect on the effective date of this Charter, shall continue in full force and effect until thereafter repealed or amended. 
ARTICLE 6. - FINANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Uniform budgeting and accounting act, MCL 141.421 et seq., MSA 5.3228(21) et seq. 

Section 6.01. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall begin on the first day of October and end on the thirtieth day of September of the following year. Such year shall constitute the budget year of the city government. 
Section 6.02. - The budget procedure. 
    On or before the first day of March, all city officers and department heads shall submit to the city superintendent an estimate of the expenditure requirements for the next fiscal year of the department or activities under their control. Such estimates shall be submitted on forms and in a manner prescribed by the city superintendent to govern the preparation, submission and the administration of the annual budget. The superintendent shall prepare a complete, itemized, balanced budget document containing the proposal for the next fiscal year, together with a five-year capital program, and shall submit it with a proposed appropriation resolution to the city council on or before the first Monday in May. 
State Law reference- Mandatory that Charter provide for an annual appropriation, MCL 117.3(h), MSA 5.2073(h). 
Section 6.03. - Budget document. 
    The budget document shall present a complete financial plan for the next fiscal year, a five-year capital program, and shall include information about all the funds of the city except trust and agency funds and special assessment funds. (For budget document purposes, a fund is defined as an independent fiscal and accounting entity with a self-balancing set of accounts.) It shall contain: 
(a)  Detailed estimates of all proposed expenditures for each department and office of the city showing the expenditures for corresponding items for the current and the last preceding fiscal year, with reasons for increases and decreases which are recommended, which shall be compared with appropriations for the current year. 
(b)  Statements of the bonded and other indebtedness of the city showing the requirements for debt retirement and interest payments, the debt authorized and unissued, and the condition of sinking funds, if any. 
(c)  Detailed estimates of all anticipated income of the city from sources other than taxes and borrowing, and a comparative statement of the amounts received by the city from each of the same or similar sources for the last preceding and the current fiscal year. 
(d)  A statement of the estimated balances or deficits, as the case may be, for the end of the current fiscal year. 
(e)  An estimate of the amount of money required to be raised from current and delinquent taxes and the amount to be raised from bond issues which, together with income from other sources, will be necessary to meet the proposed expenditures and commitments of the city operations during the coming fiscal year. 
(f)  A schedule of capital improvement projects currently in progress, those planned for continuation or completion during the coming budget year, and those planned for continuation, completion or commencement during each of the next four (4) years thereafter. 
(g)  Such other supporting schedules as the city superintendent or the council may deem necessary. 
Section 6.04. - Budget hearing. 
    A public hearing on the proposed budget shall be held before its final adoption at such time and place as the council shall direct. Such public hearing shall be held in accordance with notice and hearing requirements of state law. 
Section 6.05. - Adoption of the budget. 
    Not later than the fifteenth day of June the council shall, by resolution, adopt a balanced budget for the next fiscal year, shall appropriate from the funds of the city the sums necessary to finance the budget, and shall provide for the levy of an amount necessary to be raised by taxes upon real and personal property for municipal purposes. An appropriation shall be deemed an authorization by the council to make expenditures and to incur obligations for specific purposes set forth therein. An appropriation shall limit the amount which may be spent for such specific purposes, and may specify the period of time during which such amount may be expended. 
Section 6.06. - Budget control and amendments. 
    After the budget and the appropriation resolutions have been adopted, no money shall be drawn from the treasury nor shall any obligation for the expenditure of money be incurred except pursuant to the terms thereof. The council may amend such budget and resolution at any time so as to authorize: 
(a)  The transfer of any unexpended and unencumbered balance of an appropriation made for a specific purpose; 
(b)  The transfer of appropriations within a department, account or fund; [and/or] 
(c)  The appropriation and allocation of available revenues not included in the annual budget. 
The amending resolution shall be made only upon the concurring vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the members of the council. Any remaining unexpended and unencumbered balances of any appropriated funds at the end of the fiscal year shall revert to the general fund of the city. 
Section 6.07. - Emergency appropriations. 
    The council shall have the authority to make emergency appropriations from fund surpluses to meet urgent and immediate needs at any time during the fiscal year. Any resolution of the council authorizing such emergency appropriations shall state the nature of the emergency in detail, the specific purpose for which the appropriation is made, the amount thereof, and the fund surplus from which the appropriation is being made. 
Section 6.08. - Financial reports. 
    The city superintendent shall submit the annual financial report at the end of each fiscal year or at such other times as the council may request within the fiscal year. It shall contain data showing the relation between the estimated and the actual income of the city compared to the expenses incurred or expended to the date of the report. The council shall make adjustments to the budget and the appropriation resolution as may be required to the extent that such financial report requires to keep the budget balanced. 
Section 6.09. - Depository. 
    The city council shall designate the depository or depositories for city funds and shall provide for the regular deposit of all such funds. 
State Law reference- Designation of depositories, MCL 129.12, MSA 3.572; deposit of public moneys, MCL 211.43b, MSA 7.86. 
Section 6.10. - Withdrawal of funds. 
    All funds from the treasury shall be drawn only pursuant to authorization and appropriations of the council and upon checks executed by not less than two (2) officers who shall be designated by the city council. 
Section 6.11. - Purchasing procedure. 
    Competitive bidding for all purchases and public improvements shall be obtained where practicable and contracts awarded to the lowest and/or best bidders. Sealed bids shall be obtained for all transactions involving the expenditure of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or more and the transaction shall be evidenced by written contract, purchase order or other suitable instrument, and then submitted to and for action by the city council. Where it appears that it is to the city's advantage to contract or purchase without competitive bidding, and upon receipt of a written recommendation therefor by the city superintendent, the council may, by majority vote, waive the requirements of this section. A purchasing ordinance shall be adopted outlining and detailing specific procedures for city purchasing and for bidding city contracts. 
Section 6.12. - Audit. 
    An independent audit shall be made of all city accounts and funds at least annually and at such other times as deemed necessary by the council. The audit shall be made by a certified public accountant selected by the council to disclose the assets, liabilities, reserves and equity of the funds of the city as of a specific date and shall be prepared in manner and form as required by the uniform municipal accounting laws of the state. 
ARTICLE 7. - TAXATION AND SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS 

Section 7.01. - Power to tax. 
    The city shall have the power to lay and collect taxes for general municipal purposes. 
Section 7.02. - Limits on. 
    The total annual ad valorem property tax levy shall not exceed one and one-half (1.5) per cent (15 mills) of the assessed valuation, as equalized, of all real and personal property in the city. 
Section 7.03. - Subjects of and procedures for [taxation]. 
(a)  The subjects of ad valorem taxation for city purposes shall be the same as for state, county and school purposes under the general tax laws of the state. 
(b)  The procedures for the levy, collection and return of all state, county, school and city taxes shall be in conformity with the general law of the state except as otherwise provided herein as to city taxes. 
State Law reference- Mandatory that Charter provide that subjects of taxation for municipal purposes shall be the same as for state, county and school purposes under general law, MCL 117.3(f), MSA 5.2073(f). 
Section 7.04. - Exemptions from [taxation]. 
    No exemptions from taxation shall be allowed except as expressly required or expressly permitted by the general law of the state. 
State Law reference- Property exempt from taxation, MCL 211.1 et seq., MSA 7.7 et seq. 
Section 7.05. - Tax day and tax year. 
    The taxable status of persons and property shall be determined as of the thirty-first day of December, which shall be deemed the tax day for the immediate succeeding calendar year, which shall also be the tax year except where otherwise provided by the general law of the state. 
State Law reference- Designation of tax day, MCL 211.2, MSA 7.2. 
Section 7.06. - Preparation of assessment roll. 
    The assessor shall make and complete an assessment roll for the city in the manner and form provided in the general tax law of the state. 
State Law reference- General property tax act, MCL 211.1 et seq., MSA 7.1 et seq. 
Section 7.07. - Board of review. 
    A tax board of review shall be appointed by the council annually and shall be composed of five (5) persons who are residents of the city and have the qualifications required by this Charter. At least one (1) member must be licensed by the State of Michigan to engage in real estate transactions and at least one (1) member shall be appointed from each of the three (3) wards. During the term of office, no member of the board of review shall be a city officer, employee or candidate for elected city office. The assessor shall attend all meetings of the board of review upon its request, but shall have no right to vote on any of its decisions. Unless otherwise provided herein, the board of review shall have the same powers and perform the same duties for the purpose of reviewing and correcting the assessment roll as are conferred upon boards of review in townships by the general tax law of the state. 
State Law reference- Mandatory that Charter provide for a board of review, MCL 117.3(a), MSA 5.2073(a). 
Section 7.08. - Certification for tax levy. 
    Within three (3) days after the council has adopted the budget for the coming fiscal year, the clerk shall certify to the assessor the total amount which the council has determined shall be raised by general ad valorem tax. There shall also be certified all amounts of current or delinquent special assessments and all other amounts which the city council requires to be assessed, reassessed or charged upon any property or against any person. 
Section 7.09. - Preparation and certification of tax roll. 
    After the board of review has completed its review of the assessment roll, the assessor shall prepare the city tax roll and upon receiving the certifications of the several amounts to be raised by ad valorem taxation, the assessor shall spread the taxes as certified according to and in proportion to the several valuations set forth in the roll. To avoid fractions in computations the assessor may add such amounts as are permitted by the general tax laws of the state. Such excess created on any tax roll thereby shall belong to the city. After the assessor shall certify the tax roll it shall be delivered to the mayor who shall annex a warrant thereto directing and requiring the treasurer to collect from the persons named in the tax roll, prior to March first of the following year, the several sums set forth therein opposite their respective names as a tax or an assessment. The warrant shall grant for the purpose of collecting the taxes, assessments and charges on the tax roll, all general state law powers and immunities possessed by township treasurers for the collection of taxes. The roll shall be delivered on or before the first day of July to the treasurer for collection. 
State Law reference- Completion of review of assessments prior to first Monday in April required, MCL 211.30a, MSA 7.30(1). 
Section 7.10. - Tax lien. 
    On August first the taxes thus assessed shall become a debt due to the city from the persons to whom they are assessed. The amounts assessed on any interest in real property shall become a lien upon such real property for such amounts and for all interest and charges thereon; and all personal taxes shall become a lien on all personal property of such parties so assessed. Such lien shall take precedence over all claims, encumbrances or liens to the extent provided by the general tax laws of the state, and shall continue until such taxes, interest and charges have been paid. 
Section 7.11. - Due date and notice thereof. 
    The treasurer shall give notice of the time when said taxes will be due for collection to the taxpayers of the city by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least ten (10) days prior to the first day of August in each year, and by first class mail addressed to the owners of the property according to the names and addresses as indicated on the tax roll. Such notice shall be deemed sufficient to require the payment of all taxes assessed and any failure or defect on the part of the treasurer in giving such notice shall not invalidate the taxes as spread on the roll, or release the party or property assessed from any penalty or interest thereafter. 
Section 7.12. - Collection fees. 
    All taxes paid on or before September thirtieth of each year shall be collected by the treasurer without collection fee. Property taxes shall become overdue if they remain unpaid on October first and the treasurer shall add to all taxes paid thereafter a collection fee or fees in the amounts provided by the general tax law of the state. Such collection fees shall belong to the city and shall constitute a charge and shall be a lien against the property to which the taxes themselves applied and shall be collectable in the same manner as the taxes to which they were added. 
Section 7.13. - Unpaid personal property taxes. 
    Any personal property taxes remaining unpaid on or after October first may be collected by the treasurer by seizing the personal property against which the taxes were assessed, in an amount sufficient to pay such tax and the fees and charges for the subsequent sale thereof. No property shall be exempt from such seizure. The treasurer may sell the property seized to an amount sufficient to pay the taxes and all charges in accordance with the procedure established by the general tax law of the state. The treasurer may, in the alternative, collect such unpaid taxes by a civil action against the parties to whom such taxes were assessed and such liability shall be personal. 
State Law reference- Failure or refusal to pay tax, MCL 211.47, MSA 7.91. 
Section 7.14. - Unpaid real property taxes. 
    If the treasurer has been unable to collect any of the city taxes assessed against real property before the first day of March following the date when they come due, it shall be the treasurer's duty to return all such unpaid taxes to the county treasurer in the manner and with like effect as returns by township treasurers of township, school and county taxes. Such returns shall be made upon a delinquent tax roll to be prepared by the treasurer and shall include all the additional charges and fees added to the amount assessed. The taxes thus returned shall be collected in the same manner as other taxes returned to the county treasurer under the provisions of the general tax law of the state, and shall be and remain a lien upon the lands against which they were assessed until fully paid. 
State Law reference- Return of delinquent taxes, MCL 211.55 et seq., MSA 7.99 et seq. 
Section 7.15. - Protection of the tax lien. 
    The city shall have the power to acquire any premises within the city at any tax or other public sale, or by direct purchase from the state or the owner thereof, when such purchase is necessary to protect the lien of the city for taxes or assessments against said premises. The city may hold, lease or sell such property solely for the purpose of securing therefrom the amount of such taxes or special assessments together with any expenses incurred in connection with the exercise of this power. This power, when exercised by the city in the protection of its tax lien, shall be deemed to be in the public interest and for a public purpose. 
Section 7.16. - Additional powers [established by state law]. 
    Except as otherwise provided by this Charter or ordinance, the powers, rights and duties, immunities and procedures established by the general tax law of the state shall apply in the collection and enforcement of city property taxes. 
Section 7.17. - Special assessment powers [of council]. 
    The city council shall have power after public hearing to determine and declare by resolution that the whole or any part of the expense of a public improvement, repair or abatement of nuisance shall be defrayed by special assessments against the property specially benefited thereby. 
State Law reference- Permissible that Charter provide for assessing costs of improvements, MCL 117.4d, MSA 5.2077. 
Section 7.18. - Procedures for [special assessments]. 
    The complete special assessment procedure to be used in the making of improvements, repairs or abatement of nuisances by the special assessment method shall be established by ordinance. 
Section 7.19. - Lien for [unpaid special assessment]. 
    From and after the date of confirmation of any tax roll levying any special assessment, the city shall possess a lien on the premises subject thereto for the full amount of the unpaid special assessment and the interest on all unpaid installments thereof, and such amount shall also be a debt of the party to whom assessed until paid; and, in the case of delinquency, may be enforced as delinquent city property taxes or by a civil action for recovery against the party assessed. 
ARTICLE 8. - BORROWING POWER 

Section 8.01. - Powers and limitations on [borrowing]. 
    Limited only by the general law of the state, the city may borrow money for any purpose within the scope of its powers and for any other purpose authorized by law and may pledge its full faith and credit for the repayment thereof. 
Section 8.02. - Evidence of obligation and execution. 
    The city may issue bonds, or any other evidence of indebtedness recognized by law as security for the repayment of money borrowed, which shall be obligations of the city. They shall be executed by and bear the signature of the mayor and city clerk and the seal of the city except where otherwise provided by law. Interest coupons on bonds may be executed with facsimile signatures of the executing officials. 
State Law reference- Authority to borrow money on the credit of the city and issue bonds therefor, MCL 117.4a(1), MSA 5.2074(1). 
Section 8.03. - Limitation on authorization. 
    Any authorization for the borrowing of money shall be void if the loan shall not have been consummated within three (3) years thereafter. 
Section 8.04. - Purpose and use of proceeds. 
    Each obligation shall contain a statement of the purpose for which it is issued and the proceeds therefrom shall be limited to the purpose so stated. Any remaining proceeds after the purpose has been fulfilled shall be used to prepay the balance owing on the loan in retirement of the obligation. 
Section 8.05. - Validation of prior obligations. 
    All bonds and other obligations heretofore issued and incurred are hereby validated. 
ARTICLE 9. - NOMINATIONS AND ELECTIONS 

Section 9.01. - Electors, qualifications and registration. 
    All residents of the city having the qualifications of electors under the general law of the state shall be electors therein. The registration of electors for the purpose of voting in city elections shall be conducted in the manner provided by the general law of the state. 
State Law reference- Qualifications for registration as elector, MCL 168.492, MSA 6.1492. 
Section 9.02. - Election districts. 
    The number of election districts shall be controlled by section 2.01 of this Charter. Each election district shall be divided into as many precincts as shall be mandated by the general law of the state. 
State Law reference- Election precincts, MCL 168.654 et seq., MSA 6.1654 et seq. 
Section 9.03. - Elections. 
(a)  Manner conducted. All elections held in the city shall be conducted in the manner provided by the general law of the state for nonpartisan elections or as provided in this Charter. The electors shall vote by ballot for all officers and questions and propositions that may be submitted to them in the manner and form as authorized by the general law of the state or this Charter. 
(b)  General. The general election for all city officers required to be elected shall be held in each odd-numbered year on the Tuesday succeeding the first Monday in November unless otherwise provided by the general law of the state. 
(c)  Primary. The primary election for the nomination of nonpartisan candidates for elective city office shall be held when required in each odd-numbered year on Tuesday following the first Monday in September unless otherwise provided by the general law of the state. 
(d)  Special. Special elections may be called by resolution of the city council to be held at such times and places as the council may designate. The purpose and objectives of such special election shall be fully set forth in the resolution. 
(e)  Ballots. Ballots shall be prepared by the city clerk in accordance with the requirements of the general law of the state for nonpartisan elections. 
(f)  Voting. Voting may be by paper ballot or by mechanical device or any other means authorized by the council not inconsistent with the general election law of the state. 
(Res. No. 03-13, 8-18-2003, referendum 11-4-2003) 
State Law reference- Michigan election laws, MCL 168.1 et seq., MSA 6.1001 et seq.; mandatory that Charter provide for time, manner and means of holding elections, MCL 117.3(c), MSA 5.2073(c). 
Section 9.04. - Election commission. 
    There shall be an election commission consisting of the city attorney, city clerk and city superintendent, any two (2) of which shall have power to act. They shall select their own chairperson and rules of procedure. They shall decide all disputed or uncertain questions of procedure relating to elections except those relating to the procedures or internal affairs of a political party. 
Section 9.05. - Candidates. 
(a)  Nomination. 
(1)  Petition requirements. Nominating petitions for elective offices to be filled at the odd-year general election shall be filed with the office of the city clerk by 4:00 p.m. on the seventh Tuesday prior to the odd-year primary election. The form of nominating petitions shall be substantially as that designated by the Michigan Election Law for the nomination of nonpartisan judicial officers except they shall be signed by not less than fifteen (15) registered electors of the city. 
Editor's note- The Charter language pertaining to filing nominating petitions for the regular city election is superseded by Michigan election law MCL 168.646a(1) as amended under PA 276 of 2012. The candidate nomination petition filing deadline is 4:00 p.m., 15th Tuesday prior to even-year November election. 
(2)  Petition certification. The city clerk's office shall accept only nomination petitions which qualify pursuant to section 9.05(a)(1), and endorse thereon the time and date of filing. Within three (3) days after the deadline for filing, the clerk's office shall declare the validity and sufficiency of each petition and forthwith notify the candidate and certify the names of all qualifying candidates for submission to the electorate at the primary election. 
(3)  Who and when nominated. If upon the expiration of the time for filing nominating petitions for any elective city office, valid petitions have been filed for no more than twice the number of candidates for such office to be elected at the following regular city election, then no primary election shall be held with respect to such office. 
    If a primary election is required, candidates equal in number to twice the number of persons to be elected to each office at the next subsequent regular city election, who receive the highest number of votes at any such primary election shall be declared the nominees for the election to the respective offices for which they are candidates. The names of such candidates, together with the names of candidates who filed valid nominating petitions for any office for which no primary was held, shall be certified by the clerk to the election commission and the county clerk as nominees for the next subsequent regular city election. 
(b)  Canvass of votes cast. Following each election, the ballots shall be counted in the manner provided by the general election law of the state and the successful candidates shall be declared and certified. 
(Res. No. 03-13, 8-18-2003, referendum 11-4-2003) 
ARTICLE 10. - INITIATIVE AND REFERENDUM 

Section 10.01. - Initiative and referendum. 
    An ordinance may be initiated by petition at any time, or a referendum on an ordinance enacted by the council may be had by a petition filed within thirty (30) days of enactment, as hereinafter provided. 
Section 10.02. - Petitions. 
    An initiatory or a referendary petition shall be signed by not less than fifteen (15) per cent of the registered electors of the city who shall have signed the petition within ninety (90) days before the date of filing the petition with the clerk. An initiatory petition shall set forth the ordinance in full or have a copy attached to it that it proposes to initiate and shall not propose to initiate more than one ordinance. The petition need not be on one piece of paper but may be the aggregate of two (2) or more petition papers. All signatories on a petition shall execute it indelibly and shall place thereon after their names, the date and places of residence by street and number or by other customary designation. To each petition there shall be attached a sworn affidavit by the circulator stating the number of signatories thereto and that each signature of the person whose name it purports to be was made in the presence of the circulator. 
Section 10.03. - Filing and sufficiency. 
    All petitions shall be filed with the clerk who shall, within ten (10) days, canvass the signatures thereon to determine their sufficiency. If found to contain an insufficient number of signatures of registered electors of the city, or to be improper as to form or compliance with the provisions of this section, the clerk shall forthwith notify the person filing such petitions who shall have ten (10) days from such notification thereafter for the filing of supplemental petition papers to cure their insufficiency. When petitions are found to be sufficient and proper, the clerk shall present the petitions to the council at its next regular meeting. 
Section 10.04. - Council procedure. 
    Upon receiving an initiatory or referendary petition from the clerk, the council shall, within thirty (30) days, either: 
(a)  If it be an initiatory petition, adopt the ordinance as submitted with the petition without change in substance, or determine to submit the proposed ordinance to the electors of the city; 
(b)  If it be a referendary petition, repeal the ordinance to which the petition refers or determine to submit the proposal to the electors of the city. 
Section 10.05. - Ordinance suspended. 
    Certification by the clerk of the sufficiency of a referendary petition shall automatically suspend the operation of the ordinance in question pending either repeal by the council, or final determination by the electors, as the case may be. 
Section 10.06. - Submission to the electors. 
    Should the council decide to submit the proposal to the electors, it shall be submitted at the next election held in the city for any other purpose except any school election, or at the discretion of the council, at a special election. The results shall be determined by a majority vote of the electors voting thereon, except in cases where otherwise required by the general law of the state. 
Section 10.07. - Limitation on amendment or repeal. 
    An ordinance adopted by the electorate through initiatory proceedings may not be amended or repealed except by further initiatory or referendary proceedings for a period of two (2) years after its original adoption. 
Section 10.08. - Limitation on adoption. 
    An ordinance containing the same provision as that rejected by the electorate through initiatory or referendary proceedings cannot be adopted for a period of two (2) years from the date of the election rejecting the provision. 
Section 10.09. - Conflicting provisions. 
    Should two (2) or more ordinances having conflicting provisions be adopted at the same election, the one receiving the highest vote shall prevail as to those provisions. 
ARTICLE 11. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Section 11.01. - Surety bonds and indemnification. 
    The city shall provide, at its expense, bonds for personnel required to be bonded in such surety and in such amounts as the council may require by ordinance. The city may provide for the indemnification of councilmembers, appointees and employees for liability arising out of the performance of their official duties. 
Section 11.02. - City records and meetings. 
    All meetings or sessions of the city council shall be public, except where otherwise provided by the general law of the state, and there shall be maintained a written or printed journal in the English language of every session or meeting of the council. Such journal shall be kept in the city offices except when required for official reasons or for the purpose of safekeeping to be kept elsewhere, and this journal shall be available for inspection at all reasonable times. The council shall keep and maintain a system of records and accounts which shall conform to such uniform system as may be required by law. All records and accounts of the city shall be public. 
State Law reference- Mandatory that Charter provide for keeping in the English language a written or printed journal of every session of the legislative body, MCL 117.3(m), MSA 5.2073(m); freedom of information act, MCL 15.231 et seq., MSA 4.1801(1) et seq. 
Section 11.03. - Amendments to or revision of the Charter. 
    The Charter may be amended or revised in any manner authorized by the general law of the state whenever initiated by petition of the electors or initiated by resolution adopted by a three-fifths ( 3/5 ) vote of the council elect. In the event there are two (2) or more amendments adopted at the same election which have conflicting provisions, the one receiving the largest number of affirmative votes shall prevail as to those provisions. 
Section 11.04. - Sale or lease of real property. 
    Any agreement for the sale, the exchange, or the lease for three (3) years or more of real property, shall not be valid unless approved by the affirmative vote of five (5) members of the council; provided, however, such approval shall be subject to the approval of the electors voting thereon in the case of a sale of a park or a cemetery or any part thereof. 
Section 11.05. - Restriction on contracts or appointments. 
    No contract shall be awarded or an appointment to an official position made to anyone who is in default to the city. A default for the purpose of this section is defined as the willful failure to perform a legal obligation due the city which is not excused by law. 
Section 11.06. - Severability. 
    This Charter and each article, section, subsection, paragraph, part, provision, sentence, word and portion thereof are hereby declared to be severable, and if they or any of them are found to be invalid or unenforceable for any reason by a court of competent jurisdiction, it is hereby provided that the remainder of this Charter shall not be affected thereby. 
Section 11.07. - Penalty for violation. 
    Violations of this Charter shall be deemed misdemeanors and persons convicted thereof punishable by five hundred dollar ($500.00) fine or ninety (90) days' imprisonment, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
ARTICLE 12. - TRANSITIONAL PROVISION 

Section 12.01. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this transition article is to inaugurate the revision government of the City of St. Clair under this Charter and to provide for a continuity and transition from the prior Charter to this Charter. 
Section 12.02. - Submission to electors. 
(a)  Election. This Charter shall be submitted to a vote of the registered electors of the City of St. Clair at an election to be held on August 7, 1979. This Charter shall be adopted when approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. The city clerk shall give and publish notice of such election as required by law. 
(b)  Publication. This Charter shall be published in its entirety with or without commentary by the revision commission in the St. Clair County Independent Press, a newspaper published and circulated in the City of St. Clair, at least two (2) weeks before but not more than four (4) weeks before the date of the election at which it is submitted for approval. 
(c)  Form of ballot. The form of ballot for submission of this revised Charter for approval shall be: 
    "Shall the revised Charter drafted by the Charter Revision Commission elected November 8, 1977 be adopted?" 
? YES 
? NO  
Section 12.03. - Effective date. 
    This Charter, if adopted, shall take effect and become the basic law of the City of St. Clair for all purposes, at twelve o'clock, noon, January 1, 1980, after which date the incumbent city council shall continue to function under this Charter until a city council is elected under this Charter. 
Section 12.04. - Existing legislation and obligations. 
(a)  All ordinances and resolutions of the City of St. Clair, and all orders, rules and regulations made by any official or agency of the city, not inconsistent with this Charter, shall remain in effect until changed by action taken under this Charter. 
(b)  The city shall be vested with all property, monies, credits, contracts, records, files, books and papers belonging to it under its previous Charter. No right or liability, contract, lease or franchise, either in favor of or against the city, and no suit or prosecution of any character, shall be affected in any manner by any change resulting from the adoption of this Charter. All debts and liabilities of the city shall continue to be its debts and liabilities, and all debts owing to it and fines, penalties, interest or fees, imposed and existing at the time of such change, shall be collected by the city. Until the new city council and city superintendent herein authorized have exercised their powers with respect thereto, all appointed officials and employees of the city shall continue to have the same duties, rights, powers and compensation as existed prior to the effective date of this Charter. 
Section 12.05. - Supplemental transition legislation. 
    In all cases involving the transition of the city government under the previous Charter to this Charter, which are not covered by this article, the city council shall make necessary provisions therefor by resolution or ordinance as may be required therefor. 
Section 12.06. - Officers and employees. 
(a)  Rights and privileges preserved. Nothing in this Charter, except as otherwise specifically provided, shall affect or impair the rights or privileges of persons who are city officers, appointees, or employees at the time of its adoption. 
(b)  Continuation of office or employment. All city officers, appointees and employees will continue in their respective positions until such positions are thereafter altered, vacated or eliminated pursuant to the powers conferred by this Charter, except the offices of constable and ward supervisor, which offices are hereby abolished. 
Section 12.07. - Transfer of power. 
    If a city department, office, board or commission is eliminated by this Charter, the powers and duties given it by law shall be transferred to the city department, office, board or commission designated in this Charter, or if the Charter makes no provision therefor, then [to that department, office, board or commission] designated by the city council. 
Section 12.08. - Mandatory legislation. 
    Wherever by this Charter an action by ordinance of the city council is required to enable the exercise of any power or function of city government, such ordinance shall be enacted and in effect within the period provided in section 4.08.
