Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
  

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    This codification of ordinances shall be known and cited as the "St. Clair City Code of Ordinances." 
Charter reference- Authority to codify,  5.12. 
State Law reference- Codification authority, MCL 117.5b, MSA 5.2084(2). 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances of the city, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless they are inconsistent with the intent of the city council or the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Charter. The word "Charter" means the Home Rule Charter of the City of St. Clair, Michigan, and includes any amendment to such Charter. 
    City. The word "city" means the City of St. Clair, Michigan. 
    City council. The words "city council" or "council" mean the city council of the City of St. Clair, Michigan. 
    City superintendent. The words "city superintendent" mean the city superintendent of the City of St. Clair, Michigan, or his designee. 
    Code. The words "Code" or "this Code" mean the St. Clair City Code of Ordinances, as designated in section 1-1, and as modified by amendment, revision and by the adoption of new chapters, articles, divisions or sections. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done, as provided in this Code or in any order issued pursuant to this Code, when expressed in days, shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, except that if the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday it shall be excluded. When the time is expressed in hours, the whole of Sunday or a legal holiday, from midnight to midnight, shall be excluded. 
    County. The words "the county" mean the County of St. Clair in the State of Michigan. 
    Gender. A word importing gender shall extend and be applied to both genders and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well. 
    Health officer or health department. The words "health officer" or "health department" mean the county health officer or the county health department. 
    MCL, MSA. The abbreviations "MCL" and "MSA" mean respectively the Michigan Compiled Laws and Michigan Statutes Annotated, as amended. 
    Municipal civil infraction. The words "municipal civil infraction" mean an act or omission that is prohibited by this Code or any ordinance of the city, but which is not a crime under this Code or other ordinance, and for which civil sanctions, including, without limitation, fines, damages, expenses and costs, may be ordered, as authorized by Chapter 87 of Act No. 236 of the Public Acts of 1961, as amended. A municipal civil infraction is not a lesser included offense of a violation of this Code that is a criminal offense. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
    Officer, employee, department, board, commission or other agency. Whenever any officer, employee, department, board, commission or other agency is referred to by title only, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of St. Clair, Michigan." Whenever, by the provisions of this Code, any officer, employee, department, board, commission or other agency of the city is assigned any duty or empowered to perform any act or duty, reference to such officer, employee, department, board, commission or agency shall mean and include such officer, employee, department, board, commission or agency or deputy or authorized subordinate. 
    Person. The word "person" and its derivatives and the word "whoever" shall include a natural person, partnership, association, legal entity or a corporate body or any body of persons corporate or incorporate. Whenever used in any clause prescribing and imposing a penalty, the term "person" or "whoever" as applied to any unincorporated entity, shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
    Shall, may. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary. The word "may" is permissive. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" mean the State of Michigan. 
    Tense. Except as otherwise specifically provided or indicated by the context, all words used in this Code indicating the present tense shall not be limited to the time of adoption of this Code but shall extend to and include the time of the happening of any act, event or requirement for which provision is made therein, either as a power, immunity, requirement or prohibition. 
(Ord. No. 1999-08,  1, 9-7-99) 
State Law reference- Rules of construction, MCL 8.3 et seq., MSA 2.212 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Interpretation of Code. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this Code, or by law or implication required, the same rules of construction, definition and application shall govern the interpretation of this Code as those governing the interpretation of the Public Acts of Michigan. 
Sec. 1-4. - Captions. 
    Headings and captions used in this Code following the chapter, article, division and section numbers are employed for reference purposes only and shall not be deemed a part of the text of any section. 
Sec. 1-5. - References and notes. 
    Charter references, cross references, state law references and editor's notes in this Code are explanatory only and should not be deemed a part of the text of any section. 
Sec. 1-6. - Application to future legislation. 
    All of the provisions of this chapter, not incompatible with future legislation, shall apply to ordinances hereafter adopted amending or supplementing this Code, unless otherwise specifically provided. 
Sec. 1-7. - Reference to other sections. 
    Whenever in one section, reference is made to another section of this Code, such reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently amended, revised, recodified or renumbered unless the subject matter is changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision. 
Sec. 1-8. - Reference to offices. 
    Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any office, officer or employee of the city exercising the powers, duties or functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any transfer of functions or change in the official title of the functionary. 
Sec. 1-9. - Certain provisions saved from repeal. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code, when not inconsistent with this Code, shall affect any ordinance: 
(1)  Authorizing the issuance of bonds or borrowing of money; 
(2)  Establishing franchises or granting special rights to certain persons; 
(3)  Prescribing traffic and parking restrictions pertaining to specific streets; 
(4)  Pertaining to zoning; 
(5)  Which is not of a general and permanent nature; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. Such ordinances are on file in the city clerk's office. No offense committed or penalty incurred or any right established prior to the effective date of the Code shall be affected. 
Sec. 1-10. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted in the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-11. - Severability. 
(a)  It is the legislative intent of the city council in adopting this Code that all provisions and sections of this Code be liberally construed to protect and preserve the peace, health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the city. If any provision or section of this Code is held unconstitutional or invalid, such holding shall not be construed as affecting the validity of any of the remaining provisions or sections, it being the intent that this Code shall stand, notwithstanding the invalidity of any provision or section thereof. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall apply to the amendment of any section of this Code whether or not the wording of this section is set forth in the amendatory ordinance. 
Sec. 1-12. - General penalties and sanctions for violations of Code and city ordinances; continuing violations; injunctive relief. 
(a)  Unless a violation of this Code or any ordinance of the city is specifically designated in the Code of Ordinances as a municipal civil infraction, the violation shall be deemed to be a misdemeanor. 
(b)  The penalty for a misdemeanor violation shall be a fine not exceeding $500.00 (plus cost of prosecution), or imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or both, unless a specific penalty is otherwise provided for the violation by this Code or any ordinance. 
(c)  The sanction for a violation which is a municipal civil infraction shall be a civil fine in the amount as provided by this Code or any ordinance, plus any costs, damages, expenses and other sanctions, as authorized under Chapter 87 of Act No. 236 of the Public Acts of 1961, as amended, and other applicable laws. 
(1)  Unless otherwise specifically provided for a particular municipal civil infraction violation by this Code or any ordinance, the civil fine for a violation shall be not less than $50.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction. 
(2)  Increased civil fines may be imposed for repeated violations by a person of any requirement or provision of this Code or any ordinance. As used in this section, "repeat offense" means a second (or any subsequent) municipal civil infraction violation of the same requirement or provision (1) committed by a person within any 18-month period (unless some other period is specifically provided by this Code or any ordinance), and (2) for which the person admits responsibility or is determined to be responsible. Unless otherwise specifically provided by this Code or any ordinance for a particular municipal civil infraction violation, the increased fine for a repeat offense shall be as follows: 
a.  The fine for any offense which is a first repeat offense shall be no less than $250.00, plus costs. 
b.  The fine for any offense which is a second repeat offense or any subsequent repeat offense shall be no less than $500.00, plus costs. 
(d)  A "violation" includes any act which is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or an offense by this Code or any ordinance; and any omission or failure to act where the act is required by this Code or any ordinance. 
(e)  Each day on which any violation of this Code or any ordinance continues constitutes a separate offense and shall be subject to penalties or sanctions as a separate offense. 
(f)  In addition to any remedies available at law, the city may bring an action for an injunction or other process against a person to restrain, prevent or abate any violation of this Code or any city ordinance. 
(g)  No person or business shall engage in any activity that is in violation of any local, state, or federal statute, law, ordinance or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 1999-08,  1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 2010-04,  1, 5-17-10) 
Charter reference- Limitation on penalties,  11.07. 
State Law reference- Limitation on penalties, MCL 117.4i. 
Sec. 1-13. - Open meetings. 
    The city council shall comply with the requirements of the Open Meetings Act, Act No. 267 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1976 (MCL 15.261 et seq., as amended.

ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-26-2-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY SUPERINTENDENT 

Sec. 2-36. - Appointment; qualifications; residency. 
    The mayor with the advice and consent of the city council shall appoint a city superintendent for an indefinite term and establish by resolution the compensation for such superintendent. The superintendent shall be appointed solely on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications with special reference to training and actual experience in municipal administration. The superintendent need not be a resident of the city or state at the time of appointment, but shall be required to become a resident of the city within such period of time established by the city council unless this requirement is specifically waived by the council. 
(Code 1975,  1-80) 
Sec. 2-37. - Powers and duties. 
    The city superintendent shall be the chief administrative officer of the city and shall report to the mayor on administrative detail but shall be responsible to the mayor and council for the administration of all city affairs and administrative policy provided under this division or resolution of the city council. The city superintendent shall: 
(1)  Have all supervisory control over all municipal employees and have such appointive and other authority over city administrative officers as provided by this division or resolution of the city council. 
(2)  Direct and supervise the administration of all departments, offices and agencies of the city except as otherwise provided by the laws of the state. The city superintendent may serve as the head of any department when so designated by the city council. 
(3)  Attend all council meetings and shall have the right to participate in council discussion but shall not have any vote. 
(4)  See that all laws, ordinances and actions of the council subject to enforcement by the city superintendent or by officers subject to his direction and supervision are faithfully executed. 
(5)  Prepare and submit the annual budget and capital program to the council. 
(6)  Submit to the council and make available to the public a complete report of the finances and administrative activities of the city as of the end of each fiscal year. 
(7)  Make such other reports as the council may require concerning the operation of city departments, offices and agencies subject to the city superintendent's direction and supervision. 
(8)  Keep the council fully advised as to the status of the current budget, the overall financial condition and the future needs of the city, and make such recommendations to the council concerning the affairs of the city as he deems desirable or necessary. 
(9)  Administer the personnel and employee relation functions of the city and maintain all personnel records of city employees. 
(10)  Administer the purchasing function subject to the procedures therefor established by the city council. 
(11)  Perform such other duties as are specified by ordinance or may be required and established by action of the city council. 
(Code 1975,  1-81) 
Sec. 2-38. - Appointment of acting city superintendent. 
    The council shall designate a qualified city administrative officer to exercise the powers and perform the duties of city superintendent during the temporary absence or disability of the city superintendent. 
(Code 1975,  1-82) 
Sec. 2-39. - Removal by city council. 
    The council may remove the superintendent from office in accordance with the following procedure: 
(1)  The council shall adopt by affirmative vote of a majority of all its members a preliminary resolution which must state the reasons for removal and may suspend the superintendent from duty for a period not to exceed 30 days. A copy of the resolution shall be delivered to the superintendent within 24 hours of its adoption. 
(2)  Within five days after a copy of the resolution is delivered, the superintendent may file with the council a written request for a public hearing. This hearing shall be held at a council meeting not sooner than ten days nor later than 21 days after the request is filed. The superintendent shall file with the council a written reply to the charges not later than five days before the hearing. 
(3)  The council may adopt the final resolution of removal which may be made effective immediately by affirmative vote of a majority of all its members at any time after five days from the date when a copy of the preliminary resolution was delivered, if the superintendent has not requested a public hearing, or at any time after the public hearing in the case where one has been requested. The superintendent shall continue to receive salary until the effective date of a final resolution of removal or as otherwise required by contract. The action of the council in suspending or removing the superintendent shall not be subject to review by any court or other governmental agency. 
(Code 1975,  1-83) 
Secs. 2-40-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SERVICES 

Sec. 2-51. - Established. 
    Pursuant to section 4.01 of the Charter, a department of public services is hereby created. 
(Code 1975,  1-111) 
Sec. 2-52. - Supervision. 
    The supervision of the department of public services shall be vested in a department head, who shall be responsible to the city superintendent and who shall be appointed pursuant to section 4.02 of the Charter. 
(Code 1975,  1-114)

ARTICLE III. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-76-2-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HISTORICAL COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-86. - Creation. 
    The city hereby creates and establishes, pursuant to section 4.07 of the Charter, the historical commission of the city. 
(Code 1975,  6-30) 
Sec. 2-87. - Purpose. 
    The purpose for which the historical commission is created and established is to collect and preserve items having historical significance to the city and to establish, operate, maintain and manage a museum in connection therewith. 
(Code 1975,  6-31) 
Sec. 2-88. - Powers and authority conferred. 
    The historical commission shall have the power and authority to perform the acts enumerated in this section, together with such other powers as are necessarily incident thereto, including the following: 
(1)  Management, control and direction of the operations, personnel, buildings, grounds, facilities, historical items, articles or artifacts, equipment and fees; 
(2)  Budget preparation and control; 
(3)  Improvement and expansion of the areas described in subsection (1) of this section; 
(4)  Preparation and maintenance of records and reports; and 
(5)  Such other duties and responsibilities as determined necessary from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1975,  6-32) 
Sec. 2-89. - Rules of procedure; bylaws required. 
    Robert's Rules of Order, Revised, shall govern the parliamentary procedure of the historical commission except in the event a state statute expressly requires a different procedure. The commission shall develop a complete set of bylaws governing the internal affairs and operations of the commission, which bylaws shall not be effective until approved by the city council, who may also, at any time, revoke, modify or amend any such bylaw. 
(Code 1975,  6-33) 
Sec. 2-90. - Requirements of bylaws. 
    The bylaws of the historical commission shall, at a minimum, provide for the following: 
(1)  The procedure for calling special and regular meetings, which procedure shall comply with applicable state statutes. 
(2)  Designation of a person responsible for, and the procedure to be followed in, giving notices of commission meetings, which complies with applicable state statutes. 
(3)  Designation of a person responsible for, and the procedure to be followed in, preparing and maintaining a record of official proceedings of the commission, which shall comply with applicable state statutes. 
(4)  An enumeration and designation of the officers of the commission together with the terms of office, powers, duties and procedure for election thereof. 
(5)  A procedure for the appointment of advisory committees to serve such purposes as the commission deems necessary. 
(6)  An enumeration of the members of the commission, together with the terms of office, which shall be staggered in accordance with the Charter or in accordance with state law where provided. 
(7)  The conditions for eligibility of nonvoting members of the commission, if there are any. 
(8)  A registered address at which the commission will receive mail and other official communications. 
(9)  A fiscal year, if different from the city's. 
(10)  Such other matters as may be deemed to be advisable by the city council or the commission to be set forth in the bylaws. 
(Code 1975,  6-34) 
Sec. 2-91. - Membership. 
(a)  Qualifications and eligibility. All members of the historical commission shall be resident electors for their prescribed terms of office. Such residency requirement may be waived as provided in the Charter. Any member of the council, employee of the city or officer thereof may serve on the commission. 
(b)  Removal. Members of the commission may be removed by the city council, for cause, as provided in the Charter. 
(c)  Appointment. The mayor with the advice and consent of the city council, or the council acting on its own motion, may appoint members to staggered terms of office of the commission as provided by the bylaws thereof. 
(d)  Compensation. No member of the historical commission shall receive compensation as such, but the city council may authorize payment of reasonable and necessary expenses incurred by any such member in the performance of authorized business of the historical commission. 
(Code 1975,  6-35-6-37) 
Sec. 2-92. - Budgets and reports. 
    The historical commission shall prepare and submit a proposed budget to the city council as required by the Charter. The commission shall also prepare and file any reports, at such time and in such form as may be required by the city council, the Charter or state statute. 
(Code 1975,  6-38) 
Sec. 2-93. - Public hearing; decisions. 
    If the historical commission holds any public hearing, the hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the requirements of any applicable state statute. Decisions shall be made in accordance with principles of due process of law, and the reasons or facts relied upon in making the decision shall be set forth in the record of the proceeding. 
(Code 1975,  6-39) 
Secs. 2-94-2-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BEAUTIFICATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-106. - Created. 
    The city hereby creates and establishes, pursuant to section 4.07 of the Charter, the beautification commission of the city. 
(Code 1975,  6-46) 
Sec. 2-107. - Purpose. 
    The purpose for which the beautification commission is created and established is to aid the city administration in beautifying the city and of fostering citizen pride in their city. 
(Code 1975,  6-47) 
Sec. 2-108. - Powers and authority conferred. 
    The beautification commission shall have the power and authority to perform the acts enumerated in this section, together with such other powers as are necessarily incident thereto, including the following: 
(1)  Developing and landscaping city property; 
(2)  Recommending beautification programs for city buildings, streets, sidewalks, and other city property; 
(3)  City street tree plantings; 
(4)  Initiating and administering an awards program for those citizens and businesses who show exceptional use of landscaping in their homes and businesses, including continuation of a suggestion box; 
(5)  Urging residents to use the city flower (marigold) and the city tree (flowering crab apple) in their landscaping plans; 
(6)  Annual celebration of Arbor Day; and 
(7)  Community vegetable gardens. 
(Code 1975,  6-48) 
Sec. 2-109. - Rules of procedure; bylaws required. 
    Robert's Rules of Order, Revised, shall govern the parliamentary procedure of the beautification commission, except in the event a state statute expressly requires a different procedure. The beautification commission shall develop a complete set of bylaws governing the internal affairs and operations of the beautification commission, which bylaws shall not be effective until approved by the city council, who may also, at any time, revoke, modify or amend any such bylaws. 
(Code 1975,  6-49) 
Sec. 2-110. - Requirements of bylaws. 
    The bylaws of the beautification commission shall, at a minimum, provide for the following: 
(1)  The procedure for calling special and regular meetings, which procedure shall comply with applicable state statutes. 
(2)  Designation of a person responsible for, and the procedure to be followed in, giving notices of commission meetings, which complies with applicable state statutes. 
(3)  Designation of a person responsible for, and the procedure to be followed in, preparing and maintaining a record of official proceedings of the beautification commission, which shall comply with applicable state statutes. 
(4)  An enumeration and designation of the officers of the beautification commission, together with the terms of office, powers, duties and procedure for election thereof. 
(5)  A procedure for the appointment of advisory committees, to serve such purposes as the beautification commission deems necessary. 
(6)  An enumeration of the members of the beautification commission together with the terms of office, which shall be staggered in accordance with the Charter or in accordance with state law where provided. 
(7)  The conditions for eligibility of nonvoting members of the beautification commission, if there are any. 
(8)  A registered address at which the beautification commission will receive mail and other official communications. 
(9)  A fiscal year, if different from the city's. 
(10)  Such other matters as may be deemed to be advisable by the city council or the beautification commission to be set forth in the bylaws. 
(Code 1975,  6-50) 
Sec. 2-111. - Membership. 
(a)  Qualifications and eligibility. All members of the beautification commission shall be resident electors for their prescribed terms of office. Such residency requirement may be waived as provided in the Charter. Any member of the council, employee of the city or officer thereof may serve on the beautification commission. 
(b)  Removal. Members of the beautification commission may be removed by the city council, for cause, as provided in the Charter. 
(c)  Appointment. The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, or the council acting on its own motion, may appoint members to staggered terms of office of the beautification commission, as provided by the bylaws thereof. 
(d)  Compensation. No member of the beautification commission shall receive compensation as such, but the city council may authorize payment of reasonable and necessary expenses incurred by any such member in the performance of authorized business of the beautification commission. 
(Code 1975,  6-51-6-53) 
Sec. 2-112. - Budgets and reports. 
    The beautification commission shall prepare and submit a proposed budget to the city council as required by the Charter. The beautification commission shall also prepare and file any reports, at such time and in the form required by the city council, the Charter, or state statute. 
(Code 1975,  6-54) 
Sec. 2-113. - Public hearing; decisions. 
    In the event the beautification commission holds any public hearing, the hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the requirements of any applicable state statute. Decisions shall be made in accordance with principles of due process of law, and the reasons and facts relied upon in making the decision shall be set forth in the record of the proceeding. 
(Code 1975,  6-55) 
Secs. 2-114-2-125. - Reserved.

DIVISION 9. - PLANNING COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 2012-06, adopted July 2, 2012, amended div. 9 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former div. 9,  2-226-2-232, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the 1975 Code,  6-141-6-148; Ord. No. 1991-03,  1-3, adopted Aug. 19, 1991; and Ord. No. 2007-01,  1, adopted April 16, 2007. 

Sec. 2-226. - Created. 
    There is created a planning commission for the city, to be known as the city planning commission. The city planning commission is created in accordance with the provisions of Act No. 33 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 2008 (MCL 125.3801 et seq.) as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06,  1, 7-2-12) 
Sec. 2-227. - Membership. 
    The city planning commission shall consist of seven members, one of whom shall be a member of the city council to be selected by resolution of the city council to serve as a member ex officio with full voting rights. The remaining six members shall be appointed by the mayor. All members of the city planning commission shall serve without compensation. Eligibility for office, term of office, and removal from office, shall be governed by the provisions of section 15 of the Michigan Planning Enabling Act (MCL 125.3815) as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06,  1, 7-2-12) 
Sec. 2-228. - Powers and duties. 
    The city planning commission shall have all the duties and powers and perform all the functions provided by Act No. 33 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 2008 (MCL 125.3801 et seq.) as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06,  1, 7-2-12) 
Sec. 2-229. - Officers, meetings, records. 
(a)  The city planning commission shall, from as appointed members, annually elect a chairperson, and the city planning commission shall also fill such other offices as it may determine to be necessary and appropriate. The city superintendent or his designee, shall act and serve as the secretary and clerk of the city planning commission, and shall keep a record of all proceedings before the city planning commission, which record shall be placed on file with the city clerk. 
(b)  The city planning commission shall hold at least four regular meetings each year and may adopt rules for the transaction of its business. All business of the planning commission shall be conducted at a public meeting held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act (1976 PA 267, MCL 15.261 to 15.275). Public notice of the time, date, and place of a regular or special meeting shall be given in the manner required by that Act. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06,  1, 7-2-12) 
Sec. 2-230. - Employees and consultants; expenditures and appropriations for planning. 
(a)  The city planning commission may appoint such employees as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with city planners, engineers, architects and other consultants as it may require; provided, however, that the city planning commission shall not expend any funds or enter any contracts or agreements for expenditures in excess of amounts appropriated for the purpose by the city council. 
(b)  The city planning commission shall, on or before March 15 in each year, submit to and file with the city superintendent a written request for an appropriation of funds for city planning for the ensuing fiscal year of the city, and the city superintendent shall, in turn, present such request to the city council in the city superintendent's annual budget report. The city council may appropriate such funds for city planning as the city council shall determine to be appropriate and advisable. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06,  1, 7-2-12) 
Sec. 2-231. - Receipt and expenditure of donations. 
    The city planning commission may receive donations for purposes of carrying out its objectives and may expend any funds received in the form of a donation, in such manner as it may deem proper. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06,  1, 7-2-12) 
Sec. 2-232. - Reports and recommendations to council. 
    The city planning commission shall make reports and recommendations to the city council; provided, however, that no such recommendation shall be binding upon the city council, and such recommendation may be overruled by the city council by a vote of not less than two-thirds of its members elect. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06,  1, 7-2-12) 
Secs. 2-233-2-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - HOUSING COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-246. - Created. 
    Pursuant to Act No. 18 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1933, Extra Session (MCL 125.651 et seq., MSA 5.3011 et seq.), as amended, there is hereby created in and for the city a commission to be known as the St. Clair housing commission. 
(Code 1975,  6-156) 
Sec. 2-247. - Membership. 
(a)  Composition; appointment. The housing commission shall consist of five members to be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. City employees and officials, other than elected officials, are hereby declared eligible for appointment to the commission. 
(b)  Term. The term of office of the members of the commission shall be five years. Members of the first commission existing under this division shall be appointed for terms of one year, two years, three years, four years and five years, respectively, and annually thereafter one member shall be appointed for a term of five years. 
(c)  Compensation; removal; filling of vacancies. Members of the commission shall serve without compensation and may be removed from office by the appointing authority. Any vacancy in office shall be filled by the appointing authority for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Code 1975,  6-157) 
Sec. 2-248. - General powers and duties. 
    The St. Clair housing commission shall have all the powers and duties vested or permitted to be vested in housing commissions by Act No. 18 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1933, Extra Session (MCL 125.651 et seq., MSA 5.3011 et seq.), as amended, and any laws which are supplemented thereto, it being the intention of this section to vest in the St. Clair housing commission all powers and duties permitted by law. 
(Code 1975,  6-158) 
Sec. 2-249. - Meetings; rules of procedure; records; quorum; officers and employees. 
(a)  The housing commission shall meet at regular intervals, such meetings to be public. It shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of the proceedings. Three members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(b)  A president and vice-president shall be elected by the commission. The commission may appoint a director, who may also serve as secretary, and such other employees or officers as shall be necessary. The commission shall prescribe the duties of all its officers and employees and may, with the approval of the appointing authority, fix their compensation. The commission may, from time to time as necessary, employ engineers, architects and consultants. 
(Code 1975,  6-159) 
Sec. 2-250. - Operating funds. 
    Funds for the operation of the housing commission may be provided by the city council, but the commission shall, as soon as possible, reimburse the city for all monies expended by it for the commission from the revenues received from the sale of bonds. 
(Code 1975,  6-160) 
Sec. 2-251. - Reports to city council. 
    The housing commission shall make an annual report of its activities to the city council and shall make such other reports as the city council may, from time to time, direct. 
(Code 1975,  6-161) 
Secs. 2-252-2-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal finance act, MCL 131.1 et seq., MSA 5.3188(1) et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-271-2-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TAXATION 

Sec. 2-281. - Levy and collection of taxes in two installments. 
    The levy and collection of taxes within the city shall be in two installments. Such assessments shall be made in two separate rolls, one for the city taxes and special assessments, to be known as the city or July tax roll, and the other for the state, county and school taxes, to be known as the December tax roll, in accordance with the provisions of Act No. 215 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1895 (MCL 81.1 et seq., MSA 5.1591 et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1975,  18-1) 
Sec. 2-282. - Appointment and compensation of assessor. 
    The city council, upon the recommendation of the city superintendent, shall appoint an assessor for the city. 
(Code 1975,  18-2) 
Sec. 2-283. - Annual review of assessment roll. 
    The board of review of the city, as established by the state statutes, shall meet and notification will be provided as required by state law at which time and place the city assessor shall submit to such board the general assessment roll for review. 
(Code 1975,  18-3) 
Sec. 2-284. - Tax exemption granted housing projects by state law not applicable in city. 
    The tax exemption established in subsection (1) of Act No. 334 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1968 (MCL 125.1415a, MSA 16.114(15a)), as amended, shall not apply to housing projects located within the boundaries of the city. 
(Code 1975,  18-4) 
Secs. 2-285-2-295. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PURCHASING 

Sec. 2-296. - Purchases of city property valued at less than $500.00. 
(a)  Department heads and/or supervisors may verbally purchase, or place an order to purchase, individual items of city property up to, and including, but not to exceed, the value of $500.00, without a requisition form or purchase order. The city superintendent shall have the authority to suspend this right to purchase in his or her discretion. 
(b)  Department heads and/or supervisors shall, whenever reasonably possible, support any purchase or order made under subsection (a) of this section with a requisition form and purchase order. Failure to support such purchases or orders with such requisition form and purchase order shall not invalidate or impair such purchase. 
(Code 1975,  1-1; Ord. No. 2008-03,  1, 10-6-08) 
Sec. 2-297. - Purchase of city property valued at more than $500.00, but less than $2,500.00. 
(a)  No department head or supervisor shall purchase, or place any order for the purchase of, any individual item of city property having a value exceeding $500.00, but less than $2,500.00, until a requisition form therefor has been submitted to the city superintendent's office. 
(b)  A purchase requisition form must be properly and fully completed and signed by the department head and/or supervisor and shall contain a statement of the estimated costs of the purchase. 
(c)  The city superintendent, if he shall approve of the proposed order and purchase of the individual item of city property under this section, shall issue a completed purchase order therefor. 
(d)  Where it appears that it would be to the clear advantage of the city to do so, and where the city superintendent deems it practicable to secure competitive bids, he may require that two competitive bids be obtained for purchase orders under this section; provided, however, he shall not be obligated to do so, and the failure to secure such bids shall not invalidate or impair such purchases. 
(Code 1975,  1-2) 
Sec. 2-298. - Purchase of city property valued in excess of $2,500.00. 
(a)  Purchases, or orders for the purchases, of individual items of city property by any department head and/or supervisor having a value of $2,500.00 or greater, but less than $10,000.00, shall comply with the procedure and provisions contained in section 2-297, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  A requisition form submitted to the city superintendent's office for the purchase of any individual item of city property under this section shall be supported by no less than two written competitive quotations which have been received to serve as proof that the best possible price has been obtained. 
(c)  The city superintendent may require that such competitive bids be submitted in a form satisfactory to him, and he shall also have the authority to request additional competitive bids. 
(Code 1975,  1-3) 
Sec. 2-299. - Purchase of city property valued in excess of $10,000.00. 
(a)  No department head, supervisor, city officer or employee shall purchase, or place any order for any purchase of, any individual item of city property having a value of $10,000.00 or more, except in compliance with the requirements of the Charter, and sealed bids shall be obtained for all such purchases, and the transaction shall be evidenced by written contract, purchase order or other suitable instrument acceptable to the city council, and such contract, purchase order or other instrument shall be submitted to the city council for action. 
(b)  Notice soliciting sealed competitive bids shall be published in a newspaper in general circulation in the city at least five days prior to the final date for submitting the bids. Such notice shall briefly state the specifications of the supplies, materials, service or equipment required and shall state the amount of surety to be submitted with the bid and the surety, if any, required to be given with the contract, and shall further state the time and place for filing and opening of bids and the general terms and conditions of the award of the contract. In lieu of advertising, the city superintendent may post notices on the bulletin board in the city hall. 
(c)  The city superintendent shall, in addition, solicit sealed bids from all qualified prospective bidders known by him by sending each a copy of the notice of the proposed award. All bids shall be sealed and submitted to the city superintendent and shall be accompanied by security in the form of a cashier's check, certified check, cash or bond in such amount as prescribed in the public notice inviting bids. The city superintendent shall determine the amount of the performance bond required for construction contracts, and shall determine the amounts of the labor and materials bond required of the successful bidder. 
(d)  All bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the notice. The city council shall have the right to reject any or all bids or parts thereof and to waive any irregularities in any bid. 
(e)  After examination and tabulation, all bids may be inspected by the competing bidders. Whenever two or more low bids received are for the same total amount or unit price, the successful bidder shall be determined by vote of the city council, or whenever such action will best serve the public interest, the city superintendent with the approval of the city council may purchase the commodities in the open market, provided the price paid in the open market shall not exceed the bid price submitted for the same commodity. 
(f)  Each contract submitted to the city council for approval shall be accompanied by a tabulation of all bids received. All bids, deposits of cash, and certified or cashier's checks may be retained until the contract is awarded and signed. If any successful bidder fails or refuses to execute the contract after its award, the deposit accompanying the bid shall be forfeited and the city council may award the contract to the next lowest and best bidder or readvertise for new bids. 
(g)  A copy of each contract shall be filed with the city clerk. At the time the contract is executed by him, the contractor shall execute a surety company bond to the city, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the contract and saving the city harmless from all losses or damage caused to any person or property by reason of any carelessness or negligence by the contractor and from all expense of inspection, engineering and otherwise, caused by the delay in the completion of any improvement, and further conditioned to pay all laborers, mechanics, subcontractors and materialmen as well as all just debts and demands incurred in the performance of such work. 
(Code 1975,  1-4) 
Sec. 2-300. - Waiver of requirements. 
    Where it appears that it is to the city's advantage to contract or purchase without competitive bidding, and upon receipt of a written recommendation therefor by the city superintendent, the city council may by a majority vote waive the requirements of this division and of the Charter, as provided for in the Charter. 
(Code 1975,  1-5) 
Sec. 2-301. - Receiving slips to be submitted; inspection required. 
(a)  Receiving slips, signed by the department head and/or supervisor, shall accompany all invoices. Information on the receiving slips shall accurately describe the items of city property purchased and received, and the departmental account number against which the charge is to be made. 
(b)  The department head and/or supervisor who signs the receiving slip shall be responsible for inspection and acceptance of the materials, equipment or other items of city property to which the receiving slip applies. 
(Code 1975,  1-6) 
Secs. 2-302-2-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - COMPENSATION OF COUNCIL, MAYOR 

Sec. 2-311. - Determination for compensation. 
    The city council hereby determines that, pursuant to section 2.03(a) of the Charter, the mayor and councilmembers shall be compensated as provided in this division. 
(Code 1975,  1-120) 
Sec. 2-312. - Councilmembers' rate of compensation. 
    The annual rate of compensation for each councilmember shall be $600.00. Such compensation shall be paid in such increments and at such intervals as is most convenient to the city administration. 
(Code 1975,  1-121) 
Sec. 2-313. - Mayor's rate of compensation. 
    The annual rate of compensation for the mayor shall be $800.00, payable in the same manner as is the city council's compensation. 
(Code 1975,  1-122) 
Sec. 2-314. - Increases in compensation. 
    No provision of this division increasing the compensation of any councilmember or of the mayor shall become effective until the beginning date of the term of any councilmember elected or appointed thereafter; provided, such election or appointment follows the adoption of such an ordinance by not less than six months. 
(Code 1975,  1-123) 
Chapter 6 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; businesses, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Offenses relating to public exhibitions and entertainment, MCL 750.463 et seq., MSA 28.718 et seq.; offenses concerning coin-operated devices, MCL 752.811, MSA 28.643(101). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 6-1-6-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CIRCUSES, EXHIBITIONS, CONCERTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-26. - Hayrides. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public street means the entire width of the right-of-way of any street or road publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
(b)  Certain hayrides prohibited. No person shall operate or cause to be operated any truck, trailer, haywagon, hayrack, sled, sleigh, or other similar mechanical implement or device, nor shall any person ride upon the same, for the purpose of engaging in or participating in any hayride upon any public street within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to the use of any truck, trailer, haywagon, hayrack, sled, sleigh, or other similar mechanical implement or device in connection with the furtherance of lawful farming or agricultural operations, nor shall it apply to any truck, trailer, haywagon, hayrack, sled, sleigh, or other similar implement or device if it is used in any parade or other event lawfully permitted under any other ordinance of the city. 
(d)  Penalties. Any person violating or refusing to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine as prescribed in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(Code 1975,  2-7) 
Secs. 6-27-6-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 6-36. - For public amusements and entertainments generally. 
(a)  No person shall make or exhibit, within the limits of this city, any circus, menagerie, play, game or theatrical exhibition, any concert, vocal or instrumental, or exhibit any natural or artificial curiosity, or give any public amusement or entertainment of any kind, without a license from the city clerk, except as provided in this division. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of all persons who may be desirous of exhibiting any natural or other curiosities or shows, or to perform any games or artificial exhibitions or any other shows or public entertainments of whatever nature, to make application to the city clerk for a license, and such license may be granted, as provided in this division, by the city clerk upon the payment of the required fee as may be from time to time determined by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1975,  2-1) 
Sec. 6-37. - Temporary licenses for theatres, public halls and other places. 
    The city clerk, upon direction of the city council and upon receipt of the required fee, as may be from time to time determined by resolution of the city council, is hereby authorized and empowered to grant a temporary license for a period not exceeding three consecutive days to use and let and hire any theatre or other public hall, or other place, for the purpose of giving public entertainments and exhibitions, provided that no person who is required to be licensed under the provisions of section 18-27 of this Code shall be required to obtain an additional license under this article, except in such cases as where goods, wares and merchandise shall be offered for sale. 
(Code 1975,  2-2) 
Sec. 6-38. - Exceptions to sections 6-36 and 6-37. 
    Sections 6-36 and 6-37 shall not apply to any public amusement or entertainment or other public event which is conducted by a public school or by an organized church. 
(Code 1975,  2-3) 
Sec. 6-39. - Maintenance of order at amusement places. 
    It shall be the duty of any person receiving a license under this article to keep good order in or about his place of amusement or exhibition, and for this purpose to keep, at his expense, a sufficient police force on the premises. 
(Code 1975,  2-4) 
Sec. 6-40. - Administrative procedures. 
(a)  Form, contents of application. An applicant for a license as required in sections 6-36 and 6-37 shall make an application to the city clerk in the form and manner prescribed by the city clerk and shall state, under oath, such facts as shall be relevant to the grant of such license, including but not limited to: 
(1)  The names, businesses and residential addresses of all owners, managers and other persons who will conduct the public amusement or entertainment. 
(2)  The location at which the public amusement or entertainment will be conducted, and the name and address of the owner of the location if different than that of the applicant. 
(3)  The nature and character of the public amusement or entertainment. 
(b)  Standards for city clerk's decision. The city clerk shall, within ten days of the date on which the application is made, grant or deny an application for a license required under the terms of this division. The license shall be granted if it is determined that: 
(1)  The application is free from any fraud, misrepresentation or other materially false statement of fact. 
(2)  The public amusement or entertainment for which the application is being made will not be conducted in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or other danger to the public health, safety, morals or general welfare. 
(c)  Revocation or suspension of license. Any license may be suspended or revoked by the city clerk or police chief for not more than 15 days when he has probable cause to believe that: 
(1)  The licensee has made a materially false statement on an application for a license. 
(2)  A licensee has conducted, or is conducting, a public amusement or entertainment in an unlawful manner, or in any manner as to continue a breach of the peace or a danger to the public health, safety, morals or general welfare. 
(d)  Review by city council. Any applicant who deems himself aggrieved by any decision of the city clerk or police chief or any licensee who has had a license suspended or revoked may appeal to the city council, who shall review the action of the city clerk or police chief within 15 days of the date upon which the appeal is made. The licensee or applicant shall be reasonably notified of the time and place of the hearing and shall be given an opportunity to be heard. The city council may grant, reinstate or revoke the license, as the facts may warrant, based upon the conditions contained in subsection (b) of this section, but such action shall be taken within ten days of the date of such hearing. 
(e)  Term of license. A license granted under section 6-31 shall have an expiration date determined by the city clerk on the license. 
(f)  Transferability. No license granted under this division shall be transferable. 
(Code 1975,  2-5) 
Sec. 6-41. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this division shall be enforced by the police department of the city, and all violations shall be reported to the city clerk within three days of the discovery of the violation. 
(Code 1975,  2-5(g)) 
Sec. 6-42. - Penalty for violations of sections 6-36 through 6-39. 
    Any violation of sections 6-36 through 6-39 shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(Code 1975,  2-6) 
Secs. 6-43-6-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ARCADES AND GAME DEVICES 

Sec. 6-81. - Determination of necessity. 
    The city council hereby determines that the operation of certain game devices and arcades in the city has such an effect upon the health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants thereof that licensing and regulation of such game devices and arcades is required. 
(Code 1975,  2-67) 
Sec. 6-82. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Arcade means any place open to the public in which seven or more game devices are located for public use. 
    Game device means any machine, device or contrivance, whether electronic, mechanical or otherwise, which commences play, use or operation by the insertion of a coin, token or other similar object, or by the payment of some consideration for such operation, and which is offered to, or used by, the public for the purposes of playing a game for a contest of skill or chance. Such term shall specifically include devices such as pinball machines, video and electronic game machines, mechanical grab machines, shuffleboard game machines, and any similar devices, machines or contrivances of whatever description or trade name. The term shall not include: 
(1)  Any pool or billiard table; 
(2)  Coin-operated phonographs or merchandise vending machines; 
(3)  Coin-operated blood pressure measuring devices or weight scales; 
(4)  Coin-operated photograph booths; 
(5)  Any device inherent in the operation of a bowling alley or bingo game; or 
(6)  Any other device played as a game of chance or skill. 
    Owner means any person, including an agent or employee, who operates, conducts or has charge or control of any place or establishment in which any game device is available for operation by the public. 
(Code 1975,  2-68) 
Sec. 6-83. - Licenses for operation of arcade and game device registration required. 
    No person shall establish or operate an arcade in the city unless a license has been issued and is conspicuously displayed at all times on the premises. No person shall operate or permit the operation of any game device unless a license therefor has been issued under section 6-89 and is conspicuously displayed at all times on such premises. 
(Code 1975,  2-69) 
Sec. 6-84. - Fees. 
    The fee for each license for an arcade and the fee for each game device registered shall be as prescribed from time to time by resolution of the city council. The city council shall conduct an annual review of the fee schedule for an arcade license and game device registration. 
(Code 1975,  2-70) 
Sec. 6-85. - Locational standards for arcades. 
    All arcades located in the city shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  They shall not be located within 500 feet in any direction from the boundaries of any public, private or parochial school building, or church building. 
(2)  They shall not be located within 500 feet of each other. 
(3)  They shall conform in all respects to the requirements of the applicable city or state building, plumbing, electrical, mechanical, zoning, fire and other safety codes. 
(4)  They shall not be located in any zoning district established by the city zoning ordinance, except as permitted by special approval in either the C-1 local commercial district or C-2 general commercial district. 
(Code 1975,  2-71) 
Sec. 6-86. - Operational standards for arcades and game devices. 
    No licensee or owner of an arcade or game device or the servant, employee or agent of any such person shall permit any of the following: 
(1)  Permit the operation of any game device by any person under 16 years of age between the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., excluding Saturdays, Sundays, legal holidays, and at times when school is not in session; or to permit such persons to enter, loiter or congregate in any arcade at the times aforesaid for the purpose of operating such game devices. 
(2)  Operate the arcade between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., except on Fridays, Saturdays and legal holidays, when the arcade shall not be operated between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. This operational standard shall not apply to any business establishment duly licensed by the state liquor control commission. 
(3)  Permit gambling in any form on the premises. 
(4)  Permit any persons under the influence of intoxicating liquor or controlled substances to be on the premises. 
(5)  Permit any intoxicating liquor or any controlled substance to be brought into, sold, given away or consumed on the premises, except that this operational standard shall not apply to any business establishment duly licensed by the state liquor control commission. 
(6)  Permit disorderly or offensive conduct as defined under the ordinances of the city. 
(7)  Permit any conduct or condition to exist, contributing to juvenile delinquency. 
(8)  Permit loitering on the premises of the arcade or on sidewalks in front of the arcade, so as to obstruct a free and uninterrupted passage of the public. 
(9)  Operate the arcade unless the owner or person at least 18 years of age who is the operator, employee, servant or agent of the owner is present on the premises. 
(10)  Permit the operation of any game device containing any payoff contrivance for the return or discharge of coins, tokens, slugs, merchandise or checks to operators thereof, or to have on the premises any game device which according to federal or state law constitutes a gambling device; provided, however, that this operational standard shall not prohibit the operation of any game device which gives free play or game time to any player or user thereof who gets in excess of a specified number of points or otherwise meets a preestablished performance criteria for such free game or play time. 
(11)  Permit the operation of any game device which displays, produces or emits any picture, printed matter, advertisement, writing, song recitations, speech, music or other matter that is obscene, indecent, pornographic or harmful to minors. 
(12)  Permit any indecent, immoral, illegal and/or profane language, or indecent or immoral conduct, or permit noise or music to emerge from licensed premises, any of which causes a disturbance of the public peace. 
(Code 1975,  2-72) 
Sec. 6-87. - Issuance of arcade licenses. 
(a)  Application, required information. Application for an arcade license shall be made to the city clerk on forms provided by the clerk which shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name, date of birth, address, and telephone number of the applicant. If the applicant is a corporation, partnership or other organization, then the names, ages, addresses and telephone numbers of the officers thereof, and the owners of more than the ten percent interest therein shall also be given. 
(2)  Whether any person named or required to be named on the application has ever been convicted of a crime, and, if so, the nature of the offense, excluding minor misdemeanors not involving moral turpitude. 
(3)  The proposed number of machines or game devices intended to be operated on the premises. 
(4)  The type of machine or game device. 
(5)  The name, address and location of the proposed arcade. 
(6)  The name and address of the owner of the proposed arcade. 
(7)  The name and address of the person responsible for the operation, management and maintenance of the game devices or machines. 
(8)  The location and capacity of motor vehicle parking facilities which are to be provided for patrons using such game devices or machines at the arcade. 
(9)  A scale diagram of the arcade floor plan shall be attached to the application, showing the permanent location of each amusement machine, including electrical outlets, all aisleways, exitway discharges and doorways. A game device may not be located within five feet of any exit and the following minimum aisle widths are required where game devices are located: 
a.  Amusement machines on one side of aisle, 48 inches minimum width of aisle. 
b.  Amusement machines on both sides of aisle, 60 inches minimum width of aisle. 
(b)  Inspections. Upon receipt of the completed application and the license fee, the clerk shall cause an inspection of the premises to be made by the city building official, fire inspector and other city officials to ensure that it conforms to all applicable city codes and the standards set forth in this division. 
(c)  Withholding of license. No license shall be issued to any applicant when a person named or required to be named on the application is under the age of 18 years or has been convicted of any offense involving gambling, violation of controlled substances laws, criminal sexual conduct involving a minor, or accosting, soliciting or contributing to the delinquency of a minor. 
(d)  Issuance upon determination of eligibility. Upon the receipt of a satisfactory report based on the information required by this section, including an occupancy permit from the building official, fire inspector and other city officials, and upon a determination that the applicant is eligible for a license, based on the criteria required by this section, the clerk shall issue a license, which shall not be transferrable and which shall expire on the following December 31, regardless of the date the license was issued. 
(e)  Denial of license. If the clerk shall determine that the applicant is not eligible for a license under this article, then the applicant shall be advised of that determination, and the reasons therefor in writing. Upon the refusal or neglect of the city clerk to issue such license to an applicant within ten days of the receipt of the foregoing report, an applicant may appeal such refusal or neglect to the city council on a form to be provided to such applicant for that purpose, which form shall state the applicant's name and shall have attached thereto a copy of the information required under this division, together with other information deemed pertinent by the city clerk. 
(f)  Renewal of licenses. Licenses shall be renewed by December 31 of each year upon reinspection and satisfactory report by the city building official, fire inspector and other city officials and upon payment of the annual license fee in the same manner as in the case of the original application. 
(Code 1975,  2-73) 
Sec. 6-88. - Consent to inspection by licensee. 
    Any person obtaining a license under this division, as a condition of that license, consents to an inspection by duly authorized agents of the city during the business hours of any licensed premises. Failure to allow such inspection shall be deemed grounds for the revocation of a license. 
(Code 1975,  2-74) 
Sec. 6-89. - Registration of game devices. 
    The number of game devices kept, operated or maintained in any location open to the public in the city shall be registered with the city clerk, and the owner or custodian thereof shall obtain a license identifying the number of game devices therein. The city clerk shall maintain a record of licensed game devices, which shall include the precise number of game devices at each location and the name and addresses of the individual or parties responsible for such devices. A licensed arcade shall be limited to the number of game devices set forth in its application for a license. Licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year and shall be conspicuously displayed at all times. 
(Code 1975,  2-75) 
Sec. 6-90. - Revocation of license. 
    The city clerk shall, after a written notice to a licensee, revoke any license issued under this division when it is determined that any licensee or his agents, servants, or employees has violated any of the provisions of this division, other ordinances of the city or the laws of the state. Such notice shall specify the violation complained of and shall be delivered personally or by certified mail. A licensee under this division may appeal such revocation to the city council within ten days of the date of revocation on a form to be provided by the clerk. 
(Code 1975,  2-76) 
Sec. 6-91. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  Administration of division. The provisions of this division shall be enforced by the city superintendent who shall, in his discretion, delegate such enforcement to such of the administrative personnel of the city as he deems proper. 
(b)  Fines and imprisonment. A violation of this article shall be deemed a municipal civil infraction. 
(c)  Authority of city police. Police officers of the city shall have the power to issue citations for any violation of this division. Upon the issuance of a citation for a violation of section 6-83, the owner shall apply for a license in accordance with the requirements of section 6-87, or for the registration of the game devices, within three business days from the date of the citation. If such application is not made within three business days, the police officer shall obtain a warrant authorizing the seizure of such machines and confiscate the machines, which shall be returned to the owner only after he has complied with the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1975,  2-77; Ord. No. 1999-09,  1, 9-7-99) 
Secs. 6-92-6-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - POOLROOMS 

Sec. 6-101. - Determination of necessity. 
    The city council hereby determines that the operation of certain game devices and/or pool room facilities in the city has such an affect upon the health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants thereof that licensing and regulation of such poolrooms is required. 
(Ord. 1995-04,  1, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 6-102. - Definitions. 
    Poolroom, when used in this article, shall have the meaning of any place open to the public for playing pool or billiards, with two or more pool or billiard tables operated as a business establishment. 
(Ord. 1995-04,  1, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 6-103. - Licenses for operation of poolrooms required. 
    No person shall establish or operate a poolroom in the city unless a license has been issued and is conspicuously displayed at all times on the premises. No person shall operate or permit the operation of two or more pool or billiard tables unless a license has been issued under chapter 18, businesses, articles I and II. Such license shall be conspicuous at all times on such premises. No person shall be granted a license to operate a poolroom unless he is at least 21 years of age. No such license shall be granted except upon certification by the chief of police and the zoning administrator. 
(Ord. 1995-04,  1, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 6-104. - Fees. 
    The fee for each license for a poolroom shall be prescribed from time to time by resolution of the city council as designated in chapter 18, businesses, article II. The fee for seizure and safekeeping of any and all equipment shall be the actual cost to the city including a ten percent administrative fee. 
(Ord. 1995-04,  1, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 6-105. - Locational standards for poolrooms. 
    All poolrooms located in the city shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  They shall not be located within 500 feet in any direction from the boundaries of any public. private or parochial school building or church building. 
(2)  They shall not be located within 500 feet of each other. 
(3)  They shall conform in all respects with the requirements of applicable city and state building, plumbing, electrical and mechanical, zoning, fire and other safety codes. 
(4)  They shall not be located in any zoning districts established by the city zoning ordinance except as permitted by special use approval in the C-2 general commercial district. 
(Ord. 1995-04,  1, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 6-106. - Operational standards for poolrooms. 
    No licensee or owner of a poolroom or the employee or agent of any such person shall permit any of the following: 
(1)  Permit the operation of the poolroom between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 10:00a.m. This operational standard shall not apply to any business establishment duly licensed by the state liquor control commission. Such establishment will be subject to all other regulations as set forth by all other federal, state or city regulations or ordinances. 
(2)  Permit anyone who is less than 17 years of age or who shall falsely represent himself to be 17 years of age or older to obtain admittance or to remain in any poolroom. Not withstanding the above provisions, a person under 17 years of age may be permitted to remain in the poolroom when accompanied by his parent or legal guardian. 
(3)  Permit gambling in any form on the premises. 
(4)  Permit any persons under the influence of intoxicating liquor or controlled substances to be on the premises. 
(5)  Permit any intoxicating liquor or any controlled substance to be brought into, sold, given away or consumed on the premises, except that this operational standard shall not apply to any business establishment duly licensed by the state liquor control commission. 
(6)  Permit disorderly or offensive conduct as defined in the ordinances of the city. 
(7)  Permit any conduct or condition to exist contributing to juvenile delinquency. 
(8)  Permit loitering on the premises of the poolroom or on sidewalks in front of the poolroom so as to obstruct a free and uninterrupted passage of the public. 
(9)  Permit the obstruction of the public view by use of drawn shades, blinds or screens or advertising displays either permanent or moveable or any other device which obstructs the public view. 
(10)  Permit any indecent, illegal or profane language or indecent or immoral conduct or permit noise or music to emerge from licensed premises, any of which causes a disturbance of the public peace. 
(11)  Permit the operation of the facility without the direct supervision of an individual within the facility 21 years of age or older. 
(Ord. 1995-04,  1, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 6-107. - Consent to inspect by licensee. 
    Any person obtaining a license under this article, as a condition of that license, consents to inspection by duly authorized agents of the city during the business hours of any licensed premises. Failure to allow any such inspection shall be grounds for revocation of a license. 
(Ord. 1995-04,  1, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 6-108. - Revocation of license. 
    The city clerk, after written notice to a licensee, shall revoke any license issued under this article when it is determined that any licensee or his agents, servants or employees has violated any of the provisions of this article, other ordinances of the city or the laws of the state. Such notice shall specify the violation complained of and shall be delivered personally or by certified mail. A licensee under this article may appeal such revocation to the city council within ten days of the revocation on a form to be provided by the clerk. 
(Ord. 1995-04,  1, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 6-109. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  Administration of article. The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the city superintendent who shall, in his discretion, delegate such enforcement to such of the administrative personnel of the city as he deems proper. 
(b)  Fines and imprisonment. A violation of this article shall be deemed a municipal civil infraction. 
(c)  Authority of city police. Police officers of the city shall have the power to issue citations for any violation of this article. Upon the issuance of a citation for a violation of section 6-103, the owner shall apply for a license in accordance with the requirements of section 6-103 within three business days from the date of the citation. If such application is not made within three business days, the police officer shall obtain a warrant authorizing the seizure of such machines and confiscate the machines, which shall be returned to the owner only after he has complied with the requirements of this article and paid fees as required per section 6-104. 
(Ord. 1995-04,  1, 8-21-95; Ord. No. 1999-09,  1, 9-7-99) 
Secs. 6-110-6-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SPECIAL EVENTS 

Sec. 6-131. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, a "special event" shall mean a block party, festival, celebration, concert, or any similar occurrence or event to be conducted for a charitable, historical, educational or public or civic purpose and not for profit within any zoned district within the city, provided, however that parades and all political activities are specifically excluded from coverage under this article. 
(Ord. No. 1997-05,  1, 2-17-97) 
Sec. 6-132. - Permit required. 
    No person, firm, corporation or organization shall participate in, advertise for or in any way promote, organize, control, manage, solicit or induce participation in a special event unless a permit has first been obtained from the chief of police. No person, firm, corporation or organization shall violate any of the terms issued for a special event or the terms of this article, nor join or participate in any permitted activity under this article over the objection of a permit holder or in any manner interfere with the progress or orderly conduct of a special event. 
(Ord. No. 1997-05,  1, 2-17-97) 
Sec. 6-133. - Special events allowed pursuant to permit. 
    A person, firm, corporation or organization shall be allowed to conduct a special event in any zoned area within the city if it has first secured a permit pursuant to this article, as well as final approval from the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1997-05,  1, 2-17-97) 
Sec. 6-134. - Reimbursement for municipal expenses. 
    Upon the recommendation of the city superintendent, or by motion of the city council, that municipal expenses to be incurred in connection with the grant of a permit under this article will be unduly burdensome on the city, the city council may order, as a condition of granting the permit, that the applicant reimburse the city for the costs of city employees and for all other expenses incurred by the city in preparing for and administering the special event at rates to be periodically set by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1997-05,  1, 2-17-97; Ord. No. 2015-04,  1, 8-3-15) 
Sec. 6-135. - Application for permit. 
    An application for a permit for the holding of a special event shall be made upon a form provided by the chief of police and shall contain all of the following information: 
(1)  The name, residence and business address and phone number of each person and organization sponsoring the special event. If an organization, the application shall contain the name, residence and business addresses of the president or chairman or individual who is in charge of the event thereof; 
(2)  Description of the activity, event or use and proposed locations; 
(3)  The date(s) of and starting and ending times of the activity, event or use including time required for set-up and clean-up; 
(4)  Whether parking is requested to be restricted or prohibited during the special event and if so, in what areas; 
(5)  Proposed plans to provide necessary parking, security, crowd control, traffic control, refuse disposal, utility service, sanitation facilities, private property protection and restoration, noise control, staging areas, and other areas, personnel and equipment which is or may reasonably be necessary; 
(6)  The type, nature and amount of any rate, fee, charge to be paid or donation made by anyone participating in or attending the activity, event or use; 
(7)  Copies of insurance policies naming the city and any property owners abutting the affected street(s), road(s) or public rights-of-way as named or additional insureds in amounts of coverage to be determined from time to time by resolution of the city council and insuring the city and abutting property owners against any and all liability for damage to property and insuring the city against any and all liability for personal injury or death as a result of the activity, event or use, as a result of participation in or attendance at the activity, event or use. The city council may, at its discretion, waive these insurance requirements. 
(8)  A certification, acceptable to the city that the applicant will indemnify the city for and hold it harmless from and defend it against any and all claims, lawsuits or other liability arising from or as a result of the activity, event or use; 
(9)  The signature of an authorized person on behalf of the applicant;
