Specifically exempt from this section are those activities permitted in section 6-36, being licensed peddlers and those amplified sounds emitted from bands, orchestras, or similar musical bodies as part of a parade or similar authorized musical production, including sporting, civic, community, or school events; and those activities permitted in section 58-9, being warning devices as provided by the uniform traffic code as adopted by the city. 
d.  A violation of any provision of this section shall be deemed a public nuisance. 
(c)  None of the prohibitions enumerated in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall apply to any of the following: 
(1)  Any police vehicle, ambulance, fire engine or emergency vehicle while engaged in necessary emergency activities. 
(2)  Excavation or repair of bridges, streets or highway by or on behalf of the city, state, or the county between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. when the public welfare, safety and convenience render it impossible to perform such work during other hours. 
(d)  The provisions of this section are deemed to be in addition to any other noise regulations set out in the Code. 
(Ord. No. 1997-11,  1, 11-3-97) 
Sec. 38-150. - Obstructing peace officer. 
    No person shall resist, obstruct, hinder, oppose or refuse to obey the lawful order of any member of the police force or any peace officer in the discharge of his duties as such. 
Sec. 38-151. - Questioning suspicious persons in public places. 
    No person shall refuse to give his name, address and an explanation of his actions upon demand of a police officer who has stopped such person in a public place in the city, whom he reasonably suspects is committing, has committed or is about to commit a felony or a breach of the peace, or is violating a condition of pardon, parole or probation. 
Sec. 38-152. - Larceny. 
    Any person within the city who shall commit the offense of larceny, by stealing, of the property of another, and money, goods or chattels, or any bank note, bank bill, or bond, promissory note, due bill, bill of exchange or other bill, draft, order or certificate, or any book of accounts for or concerning money or goods due or to become due, or to be delivered, or any deed or writing containing a conveyance of land, or any other valuable contract in force, or any receipt, release or defeasance, or any writ, process or public record, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 38-153. - Receiving or concealing stolen property. 
(a)  Any person who shall buy, receive, or possess or conceal or aid in the concealment, within the city, of any stolen, embezzled or converted money, goods or property, knowing the same to have been stolen, embezzled or converted, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person who fails to make reasonable inquiry that the person selling or delivering any stolen, embezzled or converted property to him has a legal right to do so, shall be presumed to have bought or received such property knowing it to have been stolen, embezzled or converted. This presumption may be rebutted by proofs. 
(c)  In any prosecution under this section, it shall not be necessary to aver, nor on the trial thereof, to prove, that the person who stole, embezzled or converted such property has been convicted. 
Sec. 38-154. - Misrepresentations as to identity. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to make misrepresentations about his identity, whether by statement, through the use of false, forged or altered identification or the use or presentation of identification of another, with intent to obstruct the due execution of the law, or with the intent to hinder or interrupt any officer in the legal performance of his duty, whether such intent be effected or not. 
Sec. 38-155. - Trespassing. 
    Any person who shall wilfully enter, upon the lands or premises of another without lawful authority, after having been forbidden so to do by the owner or occupant, agent or servant of the owner or occupant, or any person being upon the land or premises of another, upon being notified to depart therefrom by the owner or occupant, the agent or servant of either, who without lawful authority neglects or refuses to depart therefrom, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Secs. 38-156-38-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS 

Sec. 38-176. - Lewdness and indecent exposure. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to be guilty of open and gross lewdness and lascivious behavior, or to designedly make any open or indecent or obscene exposure of his person, or of the person of another. 
Sec. 38-177. - Harassing or indecent telephone calls. 
    No person within the city shall harass, annoy or molest any other person or his family by telephoning, or causing to be telephoned, repeatedly such other person or his family, whether or not conversation ensues and regardless of the time of day or night, except for legitimate business purposes. Nor shall any person within the city use any threatening, vulgar, indecent, obscene, immoral or insulting language over any telephone. 
Sec. 38-178. - Furnishing alcoholic beverages to minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to sell or furnish alcoholic beverages to a person unless the person has attained 21 years of age. A person who knowingly sells or furnishes alcoholic beverages to a person who is less than 21 years of age, or who fails to make diligent inquiry as to whether the person is 21 years of age is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  In an action for a violation of this section, proof that the defendant or the defendant's agent demanded or was shown, before furnishing alcoholic beverages to a person under 21 years of age, a motor vehicle operator's license or an identification certificate issued by the state, or other bona fide documentary evidence of the age and identity of that person shall be a defense to an action under this section. 
Sec. 38-179. - Consumption of alcoholic liquors; exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any open container of an alcoholic beverage, or to consume any alcoholic beverage, in any public park, playground, parking area or public facility. 
(b)  Organizations and groups may obtain permission for the consumption of alcoholic beverages in a public park or facility by applying to the city manager for a special permit which may be issued with the approval of the chief of police. 
Sec. 38-180. - Possession of alcoholic liquor in passenger compartment. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person shall not transport or possess alcoholic liquor in a container that is open or uncapped or upon which the seal is broken within the passenger compartment of a vehicle upon a highway, or within the passenger compartment of a moving vehicle in any place open to the general public or generally accessible to motor vehicles, including an area designated for the parking of vehicles, in this state. 
(b)  A person may transport or possess alcoholic liquor in a container that is open or uncapped or upon which the seal is broken within the passenger compartment of a vehicle upon a highway or other place open to the general public or generally accessible to motor vehicles, including an area designated for the parking of vehicles in this state, if the vehicle does not have a trunk or compartment separate from the passenger compartment, the container is enclosed or encased, and the container is not readily accessible to the occupants of the vehicle. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(d)  This section does not apply to a passenger in a chartered vehicle authorized to operate by the state department of transportation. 
Secs. 38-181-38-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - OFFENSES INVOLVING FIRE 

Sec. 38-201. - False alarm of fire. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to knowingly raise a false alarm of fire at any gathering or in any public place, or to ring any bell or operate any public or private mechanical fire alarm apparatus to make a false report of fire in any manner whatsoever for the purpose of creating a false alarm of fire. 
Sec. 38-202. - Obstructing firefighters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to knowingly and willfully hinder, obstruct or interfere with any firefighters in the performance of their duties, or who shall, while in the vicinity of any fire, willfully disobey any reasonable order, rule or regulation of the officer commanding any fire scene. 
Sec. 38-203. - Opening fire hydrants. 
    Any person who shall, without authority of the city, open any fire hydrant, except for the purpose of extinguishing a fire, or who shall wantonly injure or impair same, or who shall, without the authority of the owner, willfully break, injure, destroy or disturb any auxiliary firefighting appliance, including fire extinguishers, sprinkler systems, standpipe systems, and the like, within the city shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Secs. 38-204-38-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY 

Sec. 38-226. - Aiming firearm. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to intentionally, without malice, point or aim any firearm at or toward any other person. 
Sec. 38-227. - Reckless, wanton use or negligent discharge of firearm. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to recklessly or heedlessly or willfully or wantonly use, carry, handle or discharge any firearm without due caution and circumspection for the rights, safety or property of others. 
Sec. 38-228. - Possession or control of firearm while intoxicated. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city, while under the influence of intoxicating beverages, or any exhilarating or stupefying drug, to carry, have in his possession or control, or use in any manner, or discharge any firearm. 
Sec. 38-229. - Possessing or carrying knives. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession or control, except in his own domicile, or carry or use in any manner any knife, dagger, dirk, razor, stiletto or any other sharp edged or pointed instrument or weapon, provided, however, that such person shall not be in violation of this section if his possession of such knife, dagger, dirk, razor, stiletto or any other sharp edged or pointed instrument is necessary for his employment, trade or occupation or if he is engaged in or is proceeding to or returning from a place of hunting, trapping or fishing and whenever required, is also carrying a currently valid license issued to him by the state department of conservation or if such person is a duly enrolled member of the Boy Scouts of American or a similar organization or society and such possession is necessary to participate in the activities of such organization or society. 
Sec. 38-230. - Manufacture, sale, or possession of certain weapons or other dangerous devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, sell, offer for sale or possess any billy, metallic knuckles, bludgeon, blackjack, sling shot, karate stick, sand gag, cross bow, BB gun, or any gas ejecting device, weapon, cartridge, container or contrivance designed or equipped for or capable of ejecting any gas which will either temporarily or permanently disable, incapacitate, injure or harm any person with whom it comes in contract. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any person duly licensed to manufacture, sell or possess any gas ejecting device, weapon, cartridge, container or contrivance as mentioned. 
Sec. 38-231. - Display of replica, toy or imitation gun. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to brandish, aim, point, or exhibit to any other person a replica or facsimile of a firearm in such manner as to frighten, threaten, harass, panic or annoy any other person. A "replica or facsimile of a firearm" shall mean any device or object which is a replica, facsimile, imitation or toy version of any firearm, including but not limited to toy guns, movie or stage props, air guns, starter pistols, inoperative firearms, models, replicas or any other device designed or used to imitate a firearm. 
Sec. 38-232. - Carrying or possessing imitation gun in public or in a motor vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or possess, whether concealed or displayed, in a motor vehicle in an area of the vehicle accessible to the occupants thereof an imitation, replica, facsimile or toy version of any firearm with intent to brandish, use, aim or point such firearm to frighten, panic, threaten, harass or annoy any other person. Carrying or conceal 
ment of any such firearm under or near the driver's seat, glove box or dashboard shall be a prima facie rebuttable inference of such intent. 
Sec. 38-233. - Confiscation of firearms. 
    All weapons, guns, pistols, firearms, knives, dirks, razors, stilettos, or any other sharp edged or pointed instruments, or weapons carried, possessed or used contrary to this article, are hereby declared forfeited to the city. 
Secs. 38-234-38-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - OFFENSES AGAINST ANIMALS 

Sec. 38-251. - Cruelty to animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, possessor or person having the charge or custody of any animal within the city to cruelly drive or work the same when unfit for labor, or to carry our cause to be carried on or upon any vehicle, or otherwise, any living animal, having the feet or legs tied together or in any cruel and inhuman manner to carry or cause to be carried any living animal, in or upon any vehicle, or otherwise, without providing suitable racks, cars, crates or cages in which such animal may stand or lie down during transportation and while awaiting slaughter, or to abandon any diseased, maimed, hopelessly sick, infirm, or disabled animal in any place, or to willfully or negligently permit and allow any aged, diseased, maimed, hopelessly sick or disabled animal to suffer unnecessary torture or pain or to otherwise maliciously inflict any torture or pain upon any animal. 
Sec. 38-252. - Attempt to commit violation. 
    Any person who shall attempt to commit an offense prohibited by this article and in such attempt shall do any act towards the commission of such offense, but shall fail in the perpetration or shall be intercepted or prevented in the execution of same, where no express provision is made by ordinance for the punishment of such attempt, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable under this Code, but in no case shall imprisonment for such violation exceed one-half the greatest punishment which might have been inflicted if the offense so attempted had been committed. 
Sec. 38-253. - Steel-jaw traps. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to use a steel-jaw (leg-hold) trap for purposes of detaining, catching or trapping wild life or domestic animals. 
Secs. 38-254-38-275. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - OFFENSES INVOLVING FRAUD 

Sec. 38-276. - Frauds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to engage in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain money or other valuable thing, or to aid or abet, or in any manner to be concerned therein. 
Sec. 38-277. - Hotel, motel, inn, restaurant, cafe, marina, boat dock, mooring or ramp; defrauding; limitation. 
    Any person within the city who shall put up at any hotel, motel, inn, restaurant, cafe, marina, boat dock, mooring or ramp as a guest and shall procure any food, entertainment or accommodation without paying therefor, except when credit is given therefor by express agreement, with intent to defraud such keeper thereof out of the pay for same, or who, with intent to defraud such keeper out of the pay therefor, shall obtain credit at any hotel, motel, inn, restaurant, cafe, marina, boat dock, mooring or ramp for such food, entertainment, or accommodation, by means of any false show of baggage or effects brought thereto is guilty of a misdemeanor. No conviction shall be had under the provisions of this section unless complaint is made within 60 days of the time of the violation hereof. 
(Ord. No. 1999-04,  1, 8-2-99) 
Sec. 38-278. - Prima facie evidence. 
    Obtaining such food, lodging or accommodation by false pretense, or by false or fictitious show of baggage or other property, or refusal or neglect to pay therefor on demand, or payment thereof with a check, draft or order upon a bank or other depository on which payment was refused, or absconding without paying or offering to pay therefor, or surreptitiously removing or attempting to remove baggage, shall be prima facie evidence of such intent to defraud. 
Chapters 39-41 - RESERVED 
Chapter 42 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 50. 

Sec. 42-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Brush means and includes tree trimmings and shrubbery cuttings up to four inches in diameter and cut into lengths not exceeding three feet in length and tied into bundles which can be readily handled by an individual collector. 
    Building material refuse means and includes wood, plaster, stone, brick or other waste and unused materials resulting from the construction or repair of buildings. 
    Dumpster means any container of more than one cubic yard capacity, whether covered or not, used for the depositing and/or temporary storage of rubbish ordinarily associated with the collection, transportation and disposal of such rubbish by motor vehicle. 
    Garbage means and includes all refuse and waste materials attendant to the preparation, dressing, cooking of, or the use and storage of food for human consumption, including wrappings. 
    Rubbish means and includes all combustible refuse, including but not limited to paper cartons, boxes, wood, tree branches, yard trimmings, wood furniture, and bedding; and noncombustible refuse, including but not limited to metals, tin cans, metal furniture, dirt, small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete, glass, crockery, and other mineral waste; provided, that the term shall not include earth and wastes from building operations. 
(Code 1975,  9-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 42-2. - Receptacles generally. 
    It shall be the duty of owners, proprietors or persons in charge of any dwelling house, store, manufacturing establishment, office building or other building within the city to place or cause to be placed all garbage and rubbish in suitable receptacles and containers provided by them. Such receptacles and containers shall be of durable metal or plastic construction and be watertight with a tightfitting cover, with handles on the outside by which they may be lifted. The cover shall be kept in place except when necessary to remove to empty such receptacle or container. 
(Code 1975,  9-2(a)) 
Sec. 42-3. - Dumpsters, screening requirements. 
(a)  All dumpsters located in the city must be enclosed or screened from public view. Such screening shall consist of a completely obscuring wall or fence not less than six feet (1.8288 meters) in height on all sides and securely fastened to a concrete or asphalt pad. They shall be maintained in good condition and the surrounding area kept free of litter and debris. It is recommended that the appearance of the screening should have some style related to its adjoining architectural motif. 
(b)  Screening materials for dumpsters shall consist of any of the following: 
(1)  Masonry, either brick, concrete block or reinforced concrete; 
(2)  Wood, provided the wood is heartwood cedar, redwood, marine grade exterior plywood or the equivalent, of at least five-eighths-inch thickness (1.5875 centimeters), or other types of wood which have been pressure treated with a preservative. If cedar, redwood or plywood are used in the screening, it shall be protected from possible rot or decay by the application of an exterior stain. Wood that has been pressure treated need not be further protected from possible rot or decay. 
(c)  All of the existing dumpsters located within the city shall comply with the provisions of this section. The city council may grant a waiver of all or part of the provisions of this section upon a finding that by reason of the shape or area of the specific property on which the existing dumpster has been installed, the strict application of this section would result in practical difficulties or undue hardship to the owner. In granting a waiver, the city council may impose reasonable conditions in fulfillment of the purpose of this section. 
(d)  This section is not intended to require the screening of any dumpster used on a temporary basis during the construction of any building, provided that such dumpster is removed from the premises or is moved to an approved, screened location on the site prior to the issuance of a final certificate of occupancy for the building under construction. 
(Code 1975,  9-2) 
Sec. 42-4. - Duty of city to collect garbage. 
    It shall be the duty of the city to arrange for a schedule of collection days for the collection of garbage, rubbish and other waste materials in the several parts of the city and to provide the necessary labor and equipment for such collections in accordance with such schedule, insofar as is practicable. 
(Code 1975,  9-3) 
Sec. 42-5. - Private collection or transportation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not an employee of the city for such purpose to collect or remove any garbage, rubbish and other waste materials from the premises where it has been created or has been formed, or to transport, cart, carry or convey through or over any of the streets, alleys or other public thoroughfares of the city any such waste materials, without permission first being received from the city superintendent. 
(Code 1975,  9-4) 
Sec. 42-6. - Placement for collection. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner, occupant or person in charge of the premises to cause to be placed in the garbage receptacles or containers garbage created or accumulated on his premises or the premises under his charge or control, and to keep the cover on at all times when not in use; and it shall be the further duty of each owner, occupant or person in charge 
of any premises to place or cause to be placed on the day scheduled by the city for the collection of garbage from premises, the receptacles or containers within a reasonable distance from the curb to such premises. When combustible rubbish is mixed with the garbage in the receptacle or container for the garbage, the container or receptacle may be placed on the outside of the sidewalk. 
(b)  Receptacles of garbage, combustible rubbish or mixtures of garbage and combustible rubbish shall be placed on the outside of the sidewalk after 12:00 noon of the day preceding the day scheduled for collection. All empty receptacles or containers are to be removed from the street the same day that the collection is made. 
(c)  Receptacles, containers and bundles of articles of noncombustible rubbish shall be placed on the outside of the sidewalk after 12:00 noon of the day preceding the day scheduled for collection, which collection day may be separate from the day scheduled for the collection of garbage and combustible rubbish, as set by the city superintendent or his authorized representative. All empty receptacles or containers are to be removed from the street the same day that the collection is made. 
(d)  All brush is to be placed outside of the sidewalk and collected by the city at such time as designated by the city superintendent. 
(Code 1975,  9-5) 
Sec. 42-8. - Collection of building material refuse, etc. 
    Concrete blocks, broken concrete, stumps and other building material refuse and other such foreign matter will not be picked up or collected by the city as a regular service and should not be included with garbage or combustible or noncombustible rubbish. Such materials will be picked up and collected by the city upon payment of a specific charge and in accordance with rules and regulations as determined by the city superintendent. 
(Code 1975,  9-8) 
Sec. 42-9. - Burying, burning or depositing on streets or vacant lots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bury, burn or throw or leave in any street, alley, public thoroughfare or vacant lot within the limits of the city any garbage or rubbish materials, except as properly placed in receptacles or containers or bundled for city collection and set in the proper location on the collection days as scheduled. 
(Code 1975,  9-9) 
Sec. 42-10. - Scavenging prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to scavenge or pick out or sort in any way any garbage or rubbish materials after they have been set out at the sidewalk for city collection. 
(Code 1975,  9-10) 
Sec. 42-11. - Rules and regulations to implement chapter. 
    The city superintendent shall adopt reasonable rules and regulations for the implementation of this chapter, which rules and regulations shall be uniform and not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter or the standards of the state department of health. 
(Code 1975,  9-11) 
Sec. 42-12. - Enforcement of chapter. 
    The chief of police and his authorized agents shall be the enforcing officers and shall be charged with the enforcement of this chapter and the regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(Code 1975,  9-12) 
Sec. 42-13. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    A violation of this chapter shall be deemed a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1975,  9-13; Ord. No. 1999-09,  1, 9-7-99) 
Chapters 43-45 - RESERVED 
Chapter 46 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 50. 
State Law reference- Notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq., MSA 5.3534(1) et seq.; deferment for older persons, MCL 211.761 et seq., MSA 5.3536(1) et seq.; powers re special assessments, MCL 117.4a, 117.4b, 117.4d, 117.5, MSA 5.2074, 5.2075, 5.2077, 5.2084. 

Sec. 46-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cost, when referring to the cost of any local public improvement, means and includes the cost of services, plans, condemnation, spreading of rolls, notices, advertising, financing, construction, legal fees, interest on special assessment bonds for not to exceed one year, and all other costs incident to the making of such improvement, the special assessments therefor and the financing thereof. 
    Local public improvement means any public improvement which is of such a nature as to benefit especially any real property within a district in the vicinity of such improvement. 
(Code 1975,  1-46) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 46-2. - Authority to assess. 
    The whole cost or any part thereof of any local public improvement may be defrayed by special assessment upon the lands specially benefited by the improvement in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1975,  1-47) 
Sec. 46-3. - Initiation of special assessment projects. 
    Proceedings for the making of local public improvements within the city, the tentative necessity thereof, and the determination that the whole or any part of the expense thereof shall be defrayed by special assessment upon the property especially benefited, provided that all special assessments levied shall be in proportion to the benefits derived from the improvements, may be commenced by resolution of the council, with or without a petition. 
(Code 1975,  1-48) 
Sec. 46-4. - Initiation by petition. 
    Local public improvements may be initiated by petition signed by property owners whose aggregate property in the proposed district represents not less than 51 percent of the total front footage of the privately owned real property located therein, all shown by the last preceding general tax records of the city. Such petition shall contain a brief description of the property owned by the respective signatories thereof, and if it shall appear that the petition is signed by at least 51 percent of the owners as aforesaid the clerk shall certify such petition to the council. The petition shall be addressed to the council and filed with the clerk and shall in no event be considered directory but is advisory only. 
(Code 1975,  1-49) 
Sec. 46-5. - Survey and report. 
    Before the council shall consider the making of any local improvement, the council shall cause to be prepared a report which shall include necessary plans, profiles, specifications and detailed estimates of cost, an estimate of the life of the improvement, a description of the assessment district, and such other pertinent information as will permit the council to decide the cost, extent and necessity of the improvement proposed and what part or proportion thereof should be paid by special assessments upon the property especially benefited and what part, if any, should be paid by the city at large. The council shall not finally determine to proceed with the making of any local public improvement until such report has been filed, nor until after a public hearing has been held by the council for the purpose of hearing objections to the making of such improvement. 
(Code 1975,  1-50) 
Sec. 46-6. - Determination on the project; notice. 
    After receiving the report required in section 46-5 for making any local public improvement as requested in the resolution of the council, and the council has reviewed such report, a resolution may be passed tentatively determining the necessity of the improvement, setting forth the nature thereof, prescribing what part or proportion of the cost of such improvement shall be paid by special assessment upon the property especially benefited, determination of benefits received by affected properties, and what part, if any, shall be paid by the city at large, designating the limits of the special assessment district to be affected, designating whether to be assessed according to frontage or other benefits, placing the complete information on file in the office of the city clerk, where such information may be found for examination, and directing the city clerk to give notice of public hearing on the proposed improvement, at which time and place opportunity will be given interested persons to be heard. Such notice shall be given by one publication in a newspaper published or circulated within the city and by first class mail addressed to each owner of or person in interest in property to be assessed as shown by the latest general tax assessment roll of the city. The publication of notice shall be made at least seven full days prior to the hearing and the mailing of notice shall be made at least ten full days prior to the date of the hearing. The notice shall include a statement that appearance and protest at the hearing in the special assessment proceedings is required in order to appeal the amount of the special assessment to the state tax tribunal and shall describe the manner in which an appearance and protest shall be made. The hearing required by this section may be held at any regular, adjourned or special meeting of the council. 
(Code 1975,  1-51) 
Sec. 46-8. - Deviation from plans and specifications. 
    No deviation from original plans or specifications as adopted shall be permitted by any officer or employee of the city without authority of the council by resolution. A copy of the resolution authorizing such changes or deviation shall be certified by the city clerk and attached to the original plans and specifications on file in the clerk's office. 
(Code 1975,  1-53) 
Sec. 46-9. - Limitations on preliminary expenses. 
    The council shall specify the provisions and procedures for financing a local public improvement. No contract or expenditure, except for the cost of preparing necessary profiles, plans, specifications and estimates of cost, shall be made for the improvement, nor shall any improvement be commenced until the special assessment roll to defray the costs of the improvement shall have been made and confirmed. 
(Code 1975,  1-54) 
Sec. 46-10. - Special assessment roll. 
    The assessor shall make a special assessment roll of all lots and parcels of land within the designated district benefited by the proposed improvement and assess to each lot or parcel of land the proportionate amount benefited thereby. The amount spread in each case shall be based upon the detailed estimate of cost as approved by the council. 
(Code 1975,  1-55) 
Sec. 46-11. - Assessor to file assessment roll. 
    When the assessor shall have completed such assessment roll, he shall file the assessment roll with the city clerk for presentation to the council for review and certification by it. 
(Code 1975,  1-56) 
Sec. 46-12. - Meeting to review special assessment roll; objections. 
    Upon receipt of the special assessment roll, the council, by resolution, shall accept the assessment roll and order it to be filed in the office of the city clerk for public examination, shall fix the time and place the council will meet to review such special assessment roll and direct the city clerk to give notice of a public hearing for the purpose of affording an opportunity for interested persons to be heard. The notice shall be given by publication one time, at least seven full days prior to the date of the hearing, in a newspaper published or circulated within the city and by first class mail addressed to each owner of or person in interest in property to be assessed as shown by the latest general tax assessment roll of the city, mailed at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. The hearing required by this section may be held at any regular, adjourned or special meeting of the council. At this meeting all interested persons or parties shall present in writing their objections, if any, to the assessments against them. The assessor shall be present at every meeting of the council at which a special assessment is to be reviewed. 
(Code 1975,  1-57) 
Sec. 46-13. - Changes and corrections in assessment roll. 
    The council shall meet at the time and place designated for the review of such special assessment roll, and at such meeting, or a proper adjournment thereof, shall consider all objections thereto submitted in writing. The council may correct the roll as to any special assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land or other errors appearing therein; or it may, by resolution, annul the assessment roll and direct that new proceedings be instituted. The same proceedings shall be followed in making a new roll as in the making of the original roll. If, after hearing all objections and making a record of such changes as the council deems justified, the council determines that it is satisfied with the special assessment roll and that assessments are in proportion to benefits received, it shall thereupon pass a resolution reciting such determinations, confirming such roll, placing it on file in the office of the city clerk and directing the city clerk to attach his warrant to a certified copy thereof within ten days, and therein commanding the assessor to spread and the treasurer to collect the various sums and amounts appearing thereon as directed by the council. 
(Code 1975,  1-58) 
Sec. 46-14. - Objection to assessment. 
    If, at or prior to the final confirmation of any special assessments, the owners of privately owned real property to be assessed for more than 50 percent of the cost of an improvement, or in the case of paving or similar improvements the owners of more than 50 percent of the frontage to be assessed for any such improvement, shall object in writing to the proposed improvement, the improvement shall not be made by proceedings delineated by this article without a five-sevenths vote of the members elect of the council. 
(Code 1975,  1-59) 
Sec. 46-15. - When due. 
    All special assessments, except such installments thereof as the council shall make payable at a future time as provided in this article, shall be due and payable upon confirmation of the special assessment roll. 
(Code 1975,  1-60) 
Sec. 46-16. - Partial payments. 
    The council may provide for the payment of special assessments in annual installments. Such annual installments shall not exceed ten in number, the first installment being due upon confirmation of the roll or on such date as the council may determine and deferred installments being due annually thereafter, or, in the discretion of the council, may be spread upon and made a part of each annual city tax roll thereafter until all are paid. Interest shall be charged on all deferred installments at a rate not to exceed the annual rate allowed by law, commencing on the due date of the first installment, or 60 days after the date of confirmation if the first installment is not due upon confirmation, and payable on the due date of each subsequent installment. The full amount of all or any deferred installments, with interest accrued thereon to the date of payment, may be paid in advance of the due dates thereof. If the full assessment or the first installment thereof shall be due upon confirmation, each property owner shall have 60 days from the date of confirmation to pay the full amount of such assessment, or the penalty. Following such 60-day period, the assessment or first installment thereof shall, if unpaid, be considered as delinquent and the same penalties shall be collected on such unpaid assessments or first installments thereof as are provided by law to be collected on delinquent general city taxes. Deferred installments shall be collected without penalty until 60 days after the due date thereof, after which such installments shall be considered as delinquent and such penalties on such installments shall be collected as are provided by law to be collected on delinquent general city taxes. After the council has confirmed the roll, the city treasurer shall notify by mail each property owner on such roll that the roll has been filed, stating the amount assessed and the terms of payment. Failure on the part of the city treasurer to give such notice or of the owner to receive such notice shall not invalidate any special assessment roll of the city or any assessment thereon, nor excuse the payment of interest or penalties. 
(Code 1975,  1-61) 
Sec. 46-17. - Delinquent special assessments. 
    Any assessment, or part thereof, remaining unpaid on the first Monday of July following the date when the assessment became delinquent shall be reported as unpaid by the treasurer to the council. Any such delinquent assessment, together with all accrued interest, shall be transferred and reassessed on the next annual city tax roll in a column headed "special assessments" with a penalty of four percent upon such total amount added thereto, and when so transferred and reassessed upon the tax roll shall be collected in all respects as provided for the collection of city taxes. 
(Code 1975,  1-62) 
Sec. 46-18. - Creation of lien. 
    Special assessments and all interest, penalties and charges thereon from the date of confirmation of the assessment roll shall become a debt to the city from the persons to whom they are assessed, and, until paid, shall be and remain a lien upon the property assessed, of the same character and effect as the lien created by general law for state, county and city taxes, and the lands upon which such assessments, interest, penalties and charges are a lien shall be subject to sale therefor the same as are lands upon which delinquent city taxes constitute a lien. 
(Code 1975,  1-63) 
Sec. 46-19. - Additional assessments, refunds. 
    The city clerk shall, within 60 days after the completion of each local or special public improvement, compile the actual cost thereof and certify such cost to the assessor who shall adjust the special assessment roll to correspond therewith. Should the assessment prove larger than necessary by less than five percent, it shall be reported to the council, which may place the excess in the city treasury or make a refund thereof pro rata according to the assessment. If the assessment exceeds the amount necessary by five percent or more, the entire excess shall be credited to owners of property as shown by the city assessment roll upon which such assessment has been levied, pro rata according to the assessment. No refunds of special assessments may be made which impair or contravene the provisions of any outstanding obligation or bond secured in whole or part by such special assessments. In the case of assessments due in installments, the council may order the refund given by credit against the installments last coming due. When any special assessment roll shall prove insufficient to meet the cost of the improvement for which it was made, the council may make an additional pro rata assessment, but the total amount assessed against any one parcel of land shall not exceed the benefits received by such lot or parcel of land. 
(Code 1975,  1-64) 
Sec. 46-20. - Collection of special assessments. 
    If bonds are issued in anticipation of the collection of special assessments as provided in this chapter, all collections on each special assessment roll or combination of rolls shall be set in a separate fund for the payment of the principal and interest on the bonds so issued in anticipation of the payment of such special assessments, and shall be used for no other purpose. 
(Code 1975,  1-66) 
Sec. 46-21. - Special assessment accounts. 
    Moneys raised by special assessment to pay the cost of any local improvements shall be held in a special fund to pay such cost or to repay any money borrowed therefor. Each special assessment account must be used only for the improvement project for which the assessment was levied, expenses incidental thereto, including the repayment of the principal and interest on money borrowed therefor, and to refund excessive assessments, if refunds are authorized. 
(Code 1975,  1-67) 
Sec. 46-22. - Written appeals. 
    If a special assessment is made against property, the notice of special assessment sent to the property owner or person responsible for payment of the ad valorem property taxes under the general property tax act shall include a statement that the owner or any person with an interest in the real property may file a written appeal of the special assessment with the state tax tribunal within 30 days after the confirmation of the special assessment roll if that special assessment was protested at the hearing held for the purpose of confirming the roll. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 211.746, MSA 5.3534(6). 
Sec. 46-23. - Reassessment for benefits. 
    Whenever the council shall deem any special assessment invalid or defective for any reason whatever, or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall have adjudged such assessment to be illegal for any reason whatever, in whole or in part, the council shall have power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made, whether the improvement or any part thereof has been completed and whether any part of the assessment has been collected or not. All proceedings on such reassessment and for the collection thereof shall be made in the manner as provided for the original assessment. If any portion of the original assessment shall have been collected and not refunded, it shall be applied upon the reassessment and the reassessment shall to that extent be deemed satisfied. If more than the amount reassessed shall have been collected, the balance shall be refunded to the person making such payment. 
(Code 1975,  1-69) 
Sec. 46-24. - Combination of projects. 
    The council may combine several districts into one project for the purpose of effecting a saving in the costs. There shall be established for each district separate funds and accounts to cover the cost of the project. 
(Code 1975,  1-70) 
Sec. 46-25. - Division of parcels. 
    Should any lots or lands be divided after a special assessment thereon has been confirmed and divided into installments, the assessor shall apportion the uncollected amounts upon the several lots and lands so divided, and shall enter the several amounts as amendments upon the special assessment roll. The city treasurer shall, within ten days after such apportionment, send notice of such action to the persons concerned at their last known address by first class mail. Such apportionment shall be final and conclusive on all parties unless protest in writing is received by the city treasurer within 20 days of the mailing of the notice. 
(Code 1975,  1-71) 
Sec. 46-26. - Deferred payments of special assessments. 
    The council may provide for the deferred payment of special assessments from persons who, in the opinion of the council and assessor, by reason of poverty are unable to contribute toward the cost thereof. In all such cases, as a condition to the granting of such deferred payments, the city shall require mortgage security on the real property of the beneficiary payable on or before his death, or in any event, on the sale or transfer of the property. 
(Code 1975,  1-72) 
Sec. 46-27. - Additional procedures. 
    In any case where the provisions of this article may prove to be insufficient to carry out fully the making of any special assessment, the council shall provide by ordinance any additional steps or procedures required. 
(Code 1975,  1-65) 
Sec. 46-28. - Single lot assessments. 
    When any expense shall have been incurred by the city upon or in respect to any single lot or parcel of land, which expense is chargeable against such lot or parcel of land and the owner thereof, pursuant to any Charter provision or ordinance or state law, and is not of that class required to be prorated among several lots or parcels of land in the special assessment district, the amount of labor and material or any such other expense or service for which such expense was incurred, with a description of the lot or parcel of land upon or in respect to which the expense was incurred, and the name of the owner, if known, shall be reported by the city superintendent to the council. The council may by resolution charge and collect said expense as a single lot assessment on either the city (summer) or county (winter) tax bill under the procedure described in this chapter. The provisions of this chapter with reference to pro rata special assessments generally, and the proceedings necessary to be had before making the improvement, shall not apply to single lot assessments contemplated in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2004-01,  1, 1-20-04) 
Chapters 47-49 - RESERVED 
Chapter 50 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 26; fire prevention and protection, ch. 30; solid waste, ch. 42; special assessments, ch. 46; subdivisions, ch. 54; traffic and vehicles, ch. 58; utilities, ch. 62; vegetation, ch. 66. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Duty of property owner or occupant to remove snow, ice, dirt, etc., from sidewalks. 
(a)  The occupant, and in case there is no occupant, the owner or person having charge, care or control of any house, building or lot within the city fronting or abutting on any street or highway within the city where sidewalks exist shall remove and clear away and keep removed and cleared away from the entire width of the sidewalk, all snow, ice, dirt, mud and other objectionable substances, within 24 hours of accumulation. 
(b)  The chief of police is hereby authorized and empowered, and it shall be his duty, if any person required by this section to remove or clear any obstruction from the sidewalks neglects or refuses so to do for 24 hours after receiving an order from the chief of police, code enforcement officer, or their duly authorized representative, requiring him to remove and clear away such obstruction, to cause such snow, ice and other obstructions to be removed and cleared away at the expense of such person. If such person refuses or neglects to pay such expense of removal on demand, such person shall be deemed to be indebted to the city in the amount of the cost and expense incurred in causing such removal and such costs may be recovered before any court of competent jurisdiction. It is expressly provided that nothing in this subsection shall be construed to excuse the neglect or failure to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section or release from the penalty provided therefor. 
(Code 1975,  16-1; Ord. No. 2015-01,  1, 6-1-15) 
Sec. 50-2. - Obstructing, injuring, etc., streets. 
    No person shall encumber or obstruct any street, alley or other highway within the city except as permitted by the city council. This section does not apply to the use of sidewalks for the display of goods and merchandise in accordance with section 50-4. 
(Code 1975,  16-2) 
Sec. 50-3. - Placing refuse from business establishments in streets or alleys. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep into, or in any manner to place or cause to be placed in any of the public streets or alleys of the city, any filth, rubbish, paper or sweepings of stores or other places of business. 
(Code 1975,  16-3) 
Sec. 50-4. - Permission required for maintenance of posts or fixtures on sidewalks. 
    No person shall put up, erect, keep, use or maintain, on or in any sidewalk in this city, any post, erection or fixture for the support of any sign, awning or advertisement, or for any other purpose, without special permission from the city council. 
(Code 1975,  16-5) 
Sec. 50-5. - Awnings, signs, etc., extending over sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall put up, erect, keep, maintain or use any awning on or over any sidewalk in this city less than seven feet above the sidewalk over which it projects. 
(b)  No person shall put up, erect, keep, use or maintain any sign, advertisement or device extending on or over the sidewalk more than three feet from the side of the wall or building to which such sign, advertisement or device is adjoined or attached, nor shall any person hang upon or fasten to any awning extending over any sidewalk any goods, wares, merchandise or other things coming nearer to the sidewalk than seven feet above such walk. 
(Code 1975,  16-6) 
Sec. 50-7. - Penalty for violation of sections 50-1 through 50-7. 
    A violation of this chapter [sections 50-1 through 50-7] shall be deemed a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1975,  16-8; Ord. No. 1999-09,  1, 9-7-99) 
Secs. 50-8-50-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR OF SIDEWALKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-04,  1, adopted Nov. 6, 2017, changed the title of art. II from "Construction of Sidewalks" to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 50-31. - Duty of property owners. 
    Every owner, or part owner, of any parcel of land within the city shall construct sidewalks along all streets and avenues in front of and adjacent thereto. 
(Code 1975,  16-20) 
Sec. 50-32. - Notice to construct. 
(a)  Wherever the city council shall, by resolution, order any sidewalk to be constructed, the city clerk shall cause notice to be given to the owner or part owner of the land in front of or adjacent to which such sidewalk is required to be built, to build the same within 30 days from the time of service of such notice. 
(b)  Such notice shall be personally served on the owner or part owner of such land, or sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to such owner or part owner at his last known address. 
(Code 1975,  16-21) 
Sec. 50-33. - Construction by city upon property owner's failure to comply with notice. 
    If the owner or part owner of land shall fail or neglect to build a sidewalk within the time specified in the notice provided for in section 50-32, the city council shall cause such sidewalk to be built and the costs thereof, including the proportion of the cost and expense of serving notices, printing and other contingencies connected therewith, or such part thereof as the council shall determine, shall be charged to such owner or part owner. The council may cause the amount of such expense incurred thereby, for which such owner or part owner shall have become liable, together with a penalty of ten percent in addition thereto, to be reported to the city assessor to be levied by him as a special tax or assessment upon the lot or premises adjacent to and abutting upon such sidewalk, which special assessment shall be subject to review. After proper notice is given as in all other cases of special assessments, such tax, when confirmed, shall be a lien upon such lot or premises the same as other special assessments, and the council shall order the city assessor to spread the amount due, together with such penalty, upon his roll as a special assessment upon such lot or premises, and the assessment shall be collected in the same manner as other city taxes. 
(Code 1975,  16-22) 
Sec. 50-34. - General specifications. 
(a)  All sidewalks within the city shall be constructed of concrete. 
(b)  Sidewalks shall be constructed as follows: The cement shall be laid upon a base of four inches of clear sand or cinders, and shall not be less than four inches in thickness and of four parts sand or gravel and one part cement, and shall not be less than four feet in width. 
(Code 1975,  16-23) 
Sec. 50-35. - Determination of grade, line and width. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons, before commencing the construction of any sidewalk, to obtain from the city superintendent the proper grade and line of such walk. It shall also be the duty of the city superintendent to determine and fix the width of any sidewalk to be constructed on or along any of the streets or avenues of the city. 
(Code 1975,  16-24) 
Sec. 50-36. - Compliance with article. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build any sidewalk on or along the streets or avenues of the city of any other or different material or of any different dimensions than are provided therefor in this article, or build any such walk except in conformity to the width, line and grade as fixed by the city superintendent, unless the city superintendent, on proper application, otherwise orders. 
(Code 1975,  16-25) 
Sec. 50-37. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    A violation of this article shall be deemed a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1975,  16-26; Ord. No. 1999-09,  1, 9-7-99) 
Secs. 50-38-50-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, adopted Oct. 19, 1998, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. The former Art. III,  50-61-50-66, pertained to street excavations and derived from Code 1975,  16-37-16-42.  Subsequently, Ord. No. 2017-04,  1, adopted Nov. 6, 2017, changed the title of art. III from "Construction and Repair" to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 50-61. - Title. 
    This article may be known as the "City of St. Clair Public Right-Of-Way Ordinance" and may be cited as such. 
(Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, 10-19-98) 
Sec. 50-62. - Declaration of purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to regulate the use of public right-of-way and to establish permit procedures and standards pertaining to the installation of facilities and structures within the public right-of-way and utility easements, encouraging joint planning of utility and telecommunication construction projects in the public right-of-way, coordinating and standardizing the location of particular kinds of facilities and structures in the public right-of-way and minimizing their interference and impairment of sidewalks, streets, sanitary sewers, storm drains or water pipes. 
(Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, 10-19-98) 
Sec. 50-63. - Definitions. 
    Unless otherwise indicated, the terms used in this article are defined as follows: 
    Alley means a public or legally established thoroughfare other than a street affording a secondary method of vehicular access to abutting property and not intended for general traffic circulation. 
    Curb means a part of the street usually of the same elevation as the center of the street which is parallel to the street which separates the portion of the roadway established for vehicular traffic from the adjacent greenbelt area designed to keep vehicular traffic from the greenbelt area. 
    Facilities and structures means poles, towers, monitoring wells, pipes, conduits, guy wires, anchors, pedestals, utility boxes, manholes, handholes, vaults, utility pits, nodes, junction boxes, buildings and enclosures, including fences. 
    Public right-of-way means the entire area owned or dedicated by the city or other governmental agency or entity for public use as a highway, street, alley or other public place. 
    Street means that portion of a public thoroughfare improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic including curbs on paved roads and shoulders on unimproved thoroughfares. 
    Utility easement means a right or privilege over a specific portion of land area granted by the owner to the public, a corporation or some particular person or persons for specific uses and purposes, and which is designated a public or private easement depending on the nature of the use. 
(Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, 10-19-98) 
Sec. 50-64. - General permit requirements. 
(a)  It is unlawful to install facilities or structures within any public right-of-way or utility easement without a permit from the city. 
(b)  It is unlawful to make any excavation or opening in or to tunnel under any public right-of-way without a permit from the city. The city superintendent or his designee may, if public safety requires, grant immediate permission to a person to make a necessary excavation or opening within the public right-of-way provided that a permit is obtained by the next business day. 
(c)  An emergency above ground repair within the public right-of-way made without a permit must be reported to the city by the next business day. 
(Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, 10-19-98) 
Sec. 50-65. - General construction requirements. 
(a)  No unnecessary damage or injury may be done to any tree or shrub or to the roots thereof. If any sidewalk is blocked by any work, a temporary sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which must be safe and convenient for travelers. 
(b)  Owners of any underground facilities and structures within a public right-of-way must participate in the Miss Dig System and respond to and stake or locate its facilities and structures within the rules and regulations as prescribed by the Miss Dig System and hold the city, its agents and contractors harmless for any damage to facilities and structures which may be damaged as a result of the city repairing or maintaining its sanitary sewers, storm drains or water mains located in any public right-of-way if due to untimely or incorrect locations being staked or identified. 
(c)  The placement of facilities and structures within public right-of-way and utility easements is subject to approval by the city engineer. The location of above ground facilities and structures are subject to review and approval by the city's site plan committee for visibility, traffic and pedestrian safety, landscaping, screening and other site conditions. 
(d)  All openings, excavations or obstructions in a public right-of-way must be properly barricaded and illuminated as required by the Michigan Manual of Uniform Traffic-Control Devices to prevent injury or damage to persons or vehicles. Safety devices must be installed at all construction sites to provide adequate notice and warning to both pedestrians and motorists. 
(e)  All openings, excavations and tunnels in a public right-of-way must be properly shored and braced in accordance with all standards promulgated by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and the Michigan Occupational Safety and Health Administration (MIOSHA) to insure the safety of all workers and prevent cave-ins and washouts which would likely cause damage to the surface grade of the street or adjoining portions of the right-of-way. If it appears that there is a danger to the public safety, the city has the authority to install any and all barricades, warning signs and other such devices that it may deem necessary and may charge the permit holder for costs incurred in protecting the public and may revoke the permit. 
(f)  Underground facilities and structures constructed of nonmetallic material are required to have a traceable metallic wrap or accompanying wire for the purpose of tracing and locating with conventional locating equipment. When placed in the public right-of-way, facilities and structures constructed of material susceptible to breakage (i.e. fiber optic line) may be encased in a protective shell as approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, 10-19-98) 
Sec. 50-66. - Application procedure. 
(a)  Application for a permit under the terms and conditions of this article and any other applicable provision of the city Code shall be made on forms provided by the city and shall be accompanied by plans and specifications showing the proposed work to be performed within the public right-of-way. 
(b)  Application for a permit may not be accepted unless it contains all of the required information, is accompanied by required plans which conform to the applicable provisions of the city Code ordinances and regulations and is accompanied by the payment of a permit fee as established by resolution of the city council from time to time. The proposed plans and specifications shall be reviewed by appropriate city departments depending on the nature of the work to be performed. 
(c)  Adequate self-insurance or liability policies naming the city as additional insured may be required by the city. A properly executed certificate of insurance containing evidence that the pertinent policy of insurance or endorsement applies to the provisions under which the permit is issued and approved as to form by the city attorney shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, 10-19-98) 
Sec. 50-67. - Construction bond and hold harmless requirement. 
    As a condition of obtaining a permit the applicant may be required to file with the city a cash construction bond in an amount of at least $1,000.00 or five percent, whichever is greater, as established by the city engineer based on the applicant's estimated cost of the project, including labor, materials and overhead, which may be utilized to pay all valid claims for damages resulting from activity within the public right-of-way. The applicant may post a blanket bond of $5,000.00 covering all new construction up to $100,000.00 per year. The estimated cost of the project shall be consistent with the installed cost of the project as reported for state and local tax purposes. The cash bond shall be conditioned to pay all damages to the public right-of-way of the city and to hold the city harmless of every damage of every other nature whether to persons or property for which such city may be held liable by reason of or which is occasioned by the doing of a thing or the exercise of the privilege for which the permit upon which the cash bond was based was granted. The applicant must execute an agreement to defend, indemnify and hold the city harmless in the event a claim arises out of an activity conducted by the applicant within the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, 10-19-98) 
Sec. 50-68. - Blanket permit and bond. 
    The owners of any facilities and structures within a public right-of-way may obtain an annual blanket work permit (January 1 to December 30) covering all maintenance and repair activities upon payment of a fee set by resolution of the city council, the posting of a cash bond in the amount of $1,000.00 and the filing of maps describing the location of all the owner's facilities and structures within the city. However, no fee maybe required of telecommunications providers except as allowed by Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002. The holder of an annual blanket work permit must file with the city upon request, a report describing the nature and location of the maintenance and repair work. The cash bond shall be conditioned to pay all damages to the public right-of-way of the city and to hold the city harmless of every damage of every other nature whether to persons or property for which such city may be held liable by reason of or which is occasioned by the doing of a thing or the exercise of the privilege for which the permit upon which the cash bond was based was granted. The applicant must execute an agreement to defend, indemnify and hold the city harmless in the event a claim arises out of an activity conducted by the applicant within the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, 10-19-98; Ord. No. 2002-03,  1, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 50-69. - Inspection of work; suspension or revocation of permit; filing of "as-built" plans with GIS data. 
(a)  All construction work done pursuant to any permit issued pursuant to this article shall be inspected by the city to determine that the work conforms with the applicable city Code provisions. The city may suspend or revoke any permit where the workmanship or materials used do not conform to the approved plans and specifications and the applicable provisions of this Code or other applicable ordinances. Violation of the terms and conditions contained in this article or any other applicable ordinance or Code provision may result in the permit being revoked. It is unlawful to perform any work authorized by any permit or cause any work to be performed after a permit has been suspended or revoked. 
(b)  "As-built" or engineering maps and plans must be submitted by the applicant to the city engineer as soon as they are completed but no later than 90 days after completion of the work; if available, a digital geographical information system layer, using a program, format and computer media acceptable to the city and containing such information and data as the city may require, which accurately displays the work. Proprietary information may be submitted under a promise of confidentiality as provided by the Freedom of Information Act. 
(Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, 10-19-98) 
Sec. 50-70. - Review procedure. 
    All operations for which a permit is granted pursuant to the terms of this division are under the direction and supervision of the city superintendent or his designee. If a permit is refused, suspended or revoked, the applicant may within ten days of the denial, suspension or revocation appeal that determination to the city council. The city council may, after proper notice to all interested parties, conduct a hearing concerning the refusal, suspension or revocation. After conducting the public hearing the city council may either affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the city superintendent or his designee. The decision of the city council is final. 
(Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, 10-19-98) 
Sec. 50-71. - Conflict between laws. 
    In the event that any parts of this article conflict with any other applicable city Code provision or ordinance of the city, the more restrictive city Code provision or ordinance shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 1998-06,  1, 10-19-98) 
Secs. 50-72-50-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BUILDING NUMBERS 

Sec. 50-86. - Required. 
    All dwellings and business houses in the city shall be numbered in the manner prescribed in this article. 
(Code 1975,  16-53) 
Sec. 50-87. - Plan. 
(a)  The numbering of houses and business places in the city shall be in accordance with the so-called "Philadelphia Plan," as near as may be. For that purpose the city shall be divided into two divisions, called north and south, and the dividing line is hereby declared to be Adams Street. 
(b)  On the north and south side of Adams Street, and on all streets running east and west, each block shall have 100 numbers. The even numbers shall be on the north side and the odd numbers on the south side. In all streets running north and south the same general plan shall be followed, the even numbers on the east side and the odd numbers on the west side, commencing at Adams Street with number 100 and running north and south to the city limits. 
(c)  All vacant lots or unplatted land shall be assigned numbers in accordance with the general plan provided for in this section. 
(d)  For the purpose of numbering, each 20 feet of frontage shall be considered a lot and assigned a number and whenever the occupancy is not in harmony therewith, the occupancy shall be assigned the number of the lot, the greater portion of which is included in such occupancy. Provided that, whenever a portion of a lot is occupied separately, it shall be numbered the same as the last preceding number with the fraction one-half added thereto. 
(Code 1975,  16-54) 
Sec. 50-88. - Map. 
    The city council shall have made a map of the city, which shall show all streets, their names, numbers and the division of each block for numbering purposes with numbers assigned as provided in this article. Such map shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk, and be open for public inspection during regular business hours. 
(Code 1975,  16-55) 
Sec. 50-89. - Attachment of and specifications for numbers. 
    The numbers provided for in this article shall be securely fastened or inscribed in a conspicuous place on the front of each building, occupancy or premises, and shall be plain, legible figures not less than two inches in length provided at the expense of each owner/occupant. 
(Code 1975,  16-56) 
Sec. 50-90. - Notice to number; failure to comply with notice. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk, whenever it is necessary to number or renumber any building, occupancy or premises under the provisions of this article, to notify the owner or occupant to that effect in writing, and should such owner or occupant refuse or neglect to do so within ten days thereafter, he shall be deemed to have violated this article, and each ten days such person shall neglect or refuse so to do, after a notice as aforesaid, shall be deemed a new violation of this section and may be prosecuted separately, and the fines and penalties provided in this article imposed for each such violation. 
(Code 1975,  16-57) 
Sec. 50-91. - Injuring or defacing numbers. 
    Any person injuring, defacing or removing the numbers or street signs or any portion thereof on any building, occupancy or premises required by the provisions of this article, whether he is the owner or occupant of such building, occupancy or premises on which such numbers or street signs are placed or not, shall be deemed to have violated this article. 
(Code 1975,  16-58) 
Sec. 50-92. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    A violation of this article shall be deemed a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1975,  16-59; Ord. No. 1999-09,  1, 9-7-99) 
Secs. 50-93-50-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - UTILITY FACILITIES 

Sec. 50-116. - Public interest; declaration as to legislative determination. 
(a)  The city council finds that utility facilities used in the transmission and distribution of gas, telephone, cable television and electrical service, such as mains, valves, wires, poles, cables, underground devices and conduits, manholes, towers and other conductors, fixtures and appurtenances necessary for the maintenance and operation of such utility businesses, are usually located over, in, under or through the streets, highways, alleys and other public places and ways of the city. 
(b)  No comprehensive local regulation and inspection of the installation and maintenance of these utility facilities has heretofore been exercised by the city, and as a result, such facilities have been installed and maintained so that their location and condition could impair, hamper and hinder the reasonable, efficient and economical use of the public rights-of-way for other public purposes. In addition, the city's ability to maintain, clean, sweep, drain, remove snow and otherwise improve and work in city streets is diminished by the presence of such utility facilities, and the city is not otherwise compensated for the additional administrative costs attributable thereto. 
(Code 1975,  16-70) 
Sec. 50-117. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cable television utility business means the activity of providing cable television services or goods to the public and includes, by way of illustration and not as a limitation, the ownership, control or management of any equipment, plant, generation machinery or devices, distribution facilities and the like for the purposes of supplying and distributing cable television services to consumers in the city. 
    Cable television utility facility means any wire, pole, cable, antenna, underground conduit, manhole, tower and other transformer, fixture, device and appurtenance of any description whatsoever necessary or used for the maintenance and operation of a cable television system in the city. 
    Electrical utility business means the activity of providing electrical energy, services or goods to the public and includes, by way of illustration and not as limitation, the ownership, control or management of any equipment, plant, generation machinery or device, distribution facility and the like for the purposes of supplying and distributing electrical energy and power to consumers in the city. 
    Electrical utility facility means any wire, pole, cable, underground conduit, manhole, transformer, fixture, device and appurtenance of any description whatsoever necessary or used for the maintenance or operation of an electrical distribution system in the city. 
    Gas utility business means the activity of providing gas energy, services or goods to the public and includes, by way of illustration and not as limitation, the ownership, control or management of any equipment, plant, generation machinery or device, storage facility and pumping device or valve, distribution facility and the like for the purposes of supplying and distributing gas energy and power to consumers in the city. 
    Gas utility facility means any main, pipe, valve, pumping device, storage facility, equipment, plant, generation machinery or device, underground conduit, manhole or other fixtures whatsoever necessary or used for the maintenance and operation of a gas distribution system in the city. 
    Legislative body means the city council. 
    Municipality means this city. 
    Streets, highways, alleys and public ways shall mean streets, avenues, highways, boulevards, concourses, driveways, bridges, tunnels, parks, parkways, waterways, docks, bulkheads, wharves, piers, alleys, all other public rights-of-way, and public places or waters within or under the jurisdiction of the city. 
    Telephone utility business means the activity of providing telephone goods or services to the public and includes, by way of illustration and not as a limitation, the ownership, control or management of any equipment, plant, generation machinery or device, distribution facility and the like for the purposes of supplying and distributing telephone service to consumers in the city. 
    Telephone utility facility means any wire, pole, cable, underground conduit, manhole, tower and other fixtures, devices and appurtenances of any description whatsoever necessary or used for the maintenance and operation of a telephone system in the city. 
    Utility business means any cable television, gas, telephone or electrical utility business having any utility facility in any street, highway, alley or public way in the city. 
    Utility facility means any cable television facility, any gas utility facility, any electric utility facility or any telephone utility facility. 
(Code 1975,  16-71) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 50-118. - Permit-Required. 
    No utility business shall install, maintain, use, operate, build, construct or otherwise place or locate any utility facility in, upon, over or through any street, highway, alley or other public place or way in the city without a permit issued under this article. Provided, however, that to the extent any provision of this article conflicts with any provision of a franchise issued by the city to a utility business, then the franchise provision shall control. 
(Code 1975,  16-72) 
Sec. 50-119. - Same-Application, fee. 
    Application for a permit to install, maintain, use, operate, build, construct or otherwise place or locate any utility facility shall be obtained from the city clerk annually, and such application shall be fully completed and returned to the clerk, together with such annual fee as may be required by resolution of the city council from time to time. The fee established by the city council shall be limited to estimated costs to be incurred by the city. 
(Code 1975,  16-73) 
Sec. 50-120. - Contents of application. 
    The application for a permit required under this article shall require the submission by the applicant of the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The number of new poles, feet of wire, pipes, mains or cable, and the number and description of other new utility facilities that the applicant proposes to locate or maintain in the city during the ensuing year. 
(3)  A complete set of construction or engineering plans and specifications for the utility business showing the location, size, nature and interrelationship of the utility facilities to be installed before a new installation is made. As-built plans of all of the utility's facilities located in the municipality shall be available for inspection at a reasonably convenient location and at reasonable business hours. 
(4)  A reliable estimate of the remaining useful life and required periodic maintenance schedule for the utility facilities to be used in the utility business. 
(5)  Identification of special problems and difficulties as to vehicular and pedestrian traffic disruption and proposed solutions therefor. 
(6)  The estimated value to the nearest $1,000.00 of the utility facilities to be located in the city. 
(7)  Copies of approvals, licenses or permits obtained from any other governmental agency for the project, if required. 
(8)  Plans for restoration of the public right-of-way. 
(9)  Such other information as may be reasonably necessary for analysis of the project under the standards of this article similar to any of the foregoing. 
(Code 1975,  16-74) 
Sec. 50-121. - Review of application; procedure and standards. 
    Upon receipt of an application, the city clerk shall forward the application to the city superintendent for his review and report.
