Thereafter, and upon receipt of the superintendent's report, the city council shall consider the application and either grant or deny the permit, or grant such permit with such conditions as the council deems advisable. The decision of the council shall be based upon the following standards: 
(1)  That all submissions required by this article have been made by the applicant, sufficient to reasonably analyze the project. 
(2)  That the proposed utility facilities do not unreasonably interfere with or impair other public uses of the street, highway, alley or public way. 
(3)  That disruption to travel by the public upon the right-of-way is not unreasonably impaired. 
(4)  That restoration of the public right-of-way to substantially its previous condition is assured. 
(5)  That the public health, safety and welfare is not unreasonably endangered by the construction of the utility facility. 
(6)  Applicable conditions and provisions of any current franchise granted by the city. 
(Code 1975,  16-75) 
Sec. 50-122. - Annual permit. 
    A permit issued under this article shall expire one year from the date of its issuance. The permit shall state the number of poles, or linear feet of wire, or linear feet of gas mains the utility business has in place in a public right-of-way on the date the permit is issued. Poles, wires and mains may be added or removed without the issuance of a new permit, but the utility facility shall notify the city clerk in writing of any such additions or removals, and of the location thereof, and a fee in the amount established by the city council shall be paid. 
(Code 1975,  16-76) 
Sec. 50-123. - Fees to be paid upon issuance of annual permit. 
    An applicant shall pay to the city treasurer an annual permit fee in an amount established by resolution of the city council from time to time pursuant to section 50-119. 
(Code 1975,  16-77) 
Sec. 50-124. - Performance measurement. 
    Within 60 days from the date of the issuance of a permit under this article, upon written request by the municipality, the utility business shall provide the municipality testing procedures to be utilized so as to ensure adherence to the technical standards required by the state public service commission. 
(Code 1975,  16-81) 
Sec. 50-125. - Insurance; indemnification, liability for damages. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided in a current franchise ordinance, within 30 days after the issuance of a permit under this article, the utility business shall file with the municipality, and maintain on file while the permit is in effect, a comprehensive general liability and comprehensive automobile liability policy sufficient to protect and satisfactory to the municipality and residents thereof from financial risks that may be incurred as a result of the utility's activities in the municipality. 
(b)  The utility business shall indemnify and hold the municipality harmless from all liability, damage, cost or expense arising from any claims against the municipality which result, directly or indirectly, from the operations conducted by the utility business in the boundaries of the municipality. The damages and penalties shall include all damages arising out of the installation, operation or maintenance of the system authorized, whether or not such act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed or prohibited by this article. To fund this liability, the utility business shall maintain a sufficient and satisfactory umbrella liability policy. 
(Code 1975,  16-86) 
Sec. 50-126. - Inspection. 
    Any utility business granted a permit under this article shall be inspected from time to time by representatives of the city to ensure compliance with the construction plans filed with the city, the requirements of this article and any conditions imposed upon the utility business by the permit. 
(Code 1975,  16-78) 
Sec. 50-127. - Construction codes. 
    The utility business shall at all times comply with all construction codes and ordinances in effect in the municipality, and with any and all rules and regulations of the state public service commission as may apply. 
(Code 1975,  16-80) 
Sec. 50-128. - Suspension and revocation of permit. 
    If the city superintendent has probable cause to believe that the utility business has violated any condition of a permit granted under this article, has varied substantially from filed construction plans, has violated any condition of this article, or is endangering the public health, safety or welfare, he may suspend the permit for a period of not more than 14 days. Thereafter, the city council shall conduct a public hearing upon the suspension, and if it is found that the suspension of the permit was warranted, and that the act or omission complained of has not been remedied, the permit shall be revoked. At the hearing, the utility business may appear and cross-examine witnesses, be represented by counsel, and shall be given notice of the specifications of the charges and notice of the hearing. 
(Code 1975,  16-79) 
Sec. 50-129. - Overhead and underground construction requirements. 
    Where facilities and equipment exist for the overhead installation of the utility business's lines, such facilities and equipment may be utilized. Where facilities and equipment are unavailable, the utility business's lines shall be installed underground. The municipality may vary the requirement for underground line installation if the utility business establishes to the satisfaction of the legislative body that underground installation cannot be accomplished due to undue hardship and/or practical difficulties. The rates charged for such installations shall be those established by the state public service commission. 
(Code 1975,  16-82) 
Sec. 50-130. - Tree trimming. 
    The utility business shall trim trees when necessary to make the lines safe and accessible and such trimming shall be done in compliance with all existing governmental laws, ordinances, rules or regulations. The utility business shall defend, hold harmless and indemnify the municipality from any or all actions, causes of actions or damages caused as a result of such activity. 
(Code 1975,  16-83) 
Sec. 50-131. - Right of inspection and restoration. 
    In case of any disturbance of pavement, sidewalk, driveway or other surfacing, the utility business shall, at its own cost and expense, and in a manner approved by the municipality, replace and restore all paving, sidewalks, driveways or other surface of any street or other alley disturbed in as good a condition as before such work was commenced. All such work shall be subject to inspection by municipal authorities. 
(Code 1975,  16-85) 
Sec. 50-132. - Construction approval by municipality. 
    Except for individual service drops and connections, and in cases of emergency, and except as otherwise provided in section 50-122, a utility business shall not erect any pole, install any underground lines or conduits, run any line, main or other utility facility, or make any attachment, or engage in construction of any kind without the prior approval of the city superintendent or such other department or engineering consultant as the municipality may from time to time determine is appropriate. Such approval will not be unreasonably withheld and the municipality shall have and maintain the right to inspect the construction, operation and maintenance of the system to ensure the proper performance and compliance with the regulatory provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975,  16-87) 
Sec. 50-133. - Relocation to accommodate public and private improvements. 
    If at any time this municipality or any other municipal corporation shall lawfully elect to alter or change the grade or location of any highway, street, alley or other public place, the utility business, upon reasonable notice by this municipality, or such other municipal corporation, shall remove, reposition and relocate its utility facilities at its own expense. If the municipality is reimbursed for the relocation costs by a third party, the utility shall receive the benefit of such reimbursement. A utility business shall, on the request of any person holding an appropriate permit issued by the municipality, temporarily raise or lower its lines to permit the moving of any building or other structure. 
(Code 1975,  16-84) 
Sec. 50-134. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    A violation of this article shall be a misdemeanor which shall be punishable upon conviction thereof as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(Code 1975,  16-88) 
Sec. 50-135. - Injunctive relief. 
    In lieu of or in addition to the remedy provided for by section 50-134, the city may petition a court of competent jurisdiction for injunctive relief or other appropriate civil remedies to prevent violations of this article. 
(Code 1975,  16-89) 
Chapters 51-53 - RESERVED 
Chapter 54 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 26; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 50; utilities, ch. 62; vegetation, ch. 66. 
State Law reference- Subdivision control act, MCL 560.101 et seq., MSA 26.430(101) et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Partition or division of land in recorded plat. 
(a)  This section is adopted pursuant to MCL 560.263, MSA 26.430(263), being a part of the Subdivision Control Act of 1967. 
(b)  No lot, outlot or other parcel of land in a recorded plat lying within the boundaries of the city shall be further partitioned or divided unless such partition or division is approved by a majority vote of the city council voting thereon. 
(c)  In no case may the partition or division of any lot, outlot or other parcel in a recorded plat be divided into more than four parts; provided, that any lot, outlot or other parcel of land in a recorded plat not served by public sewer and public water systems shall not be further partitioned or divided if the resulting lots, outlots or other parcels of land are less than the minimum size provided for in the city's zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1975,  17-1) 
Secs. 54-2-54-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-26. - Purposes. 
    The purposes of this article are to: 
(1)  Provide for the orderly growth and harmonious development of the community; 
(2)  Secure adequate traffic circulation through coordinated street systems with relation to major thoroughfares, adjoining subdivisions and public facilities; 
(3)  Achieve individual property lots of maximum utility and livability; 
(4)  Secure adequate provisions for water supply, drainage and sanitary sewerage and other health requirements; 
(5)  Secure adequate provisions for recreational areas and other public facilities; and 
(6)  Provide logical procedures for the achievement of these purposes. 
(Code 1975,  17-13) 
Sec. 54-28. - Variances. 
    The governing body may permit variances from this article, provided that such variances are not in conflict with the intent and purpose of this article and provided further that strict compliance with these criteria would render a particular parcel of land unplattable. 
(Code 1975,  17-15) 
Sec. 54-29. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, whether such person is the owner or agent of the owner of the property, shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(Code 1975,  17-16) 
Secs. 54-30-54-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURE 

Sec. 54-41. - Stages of preparation for platting. 
    The preparation of a subdivision for platting shall be carried out through two phases, preliminary plat and final plat, in accordance with the procedures set out in this division. 
(Code 1975,  17-27) 
Sec. 54-42. - Initial investigation. 
    Prior to the preparation of a preliminary plat, it is suggested that the proprietor meet informally with the municipal departments concerned to investigate the procedures and standards of the municipality with reference to this article and with the proposals of the master plan as they affect the area in which the proposed subdivision is located. The proprietor should not submit a preliminary plat at this time. The proprietor should concern himself with the following factors: 
(1)  The proprietor shall secure a copy of the zoning ordinance, subdivision regulations, engineering specifications, and other similar ordinances or controls relative to the subdivision and improvement of land so as to make himself aware of the requirements of the municipality. 
(2)  The area for the proposed subdivision shall be properly zoned for the intended use. 
(3)  An investigation of adequacy of existing schools and the adequacy of public open spaces, including parks and playgrounds to serve the proposed subdivision, shall be made by the proprietor. 
(4)  The relationship of the proposed subdivision with respect to major thoroughfares and plans for widening of thoroughfares shall be investigated by the proprietor. 
(5)  Standards for sewage disposal, water supply and drainage of the municipality shall be investigated by the proprietor. 
(Code 1975,  17-28) 
Sec. 54-43. - Preliminary plat. 
    The procedure for the preparation and review of a preliminary plat requires tentative and final approval is as follows: 
(1)  Content. The preliminary plat shall include the following: 
a.  Identification and description. 
1.  Proposed name of subdivision. 
2.  Location by section, town and range, or by other legal description. 
3.  Names and addresses of the proprietor, owner, and the planner, designer, engineer or surveyor who designed the subdivision layout. The proprietor shall also indicate his interest in the land. 
4.  Scale of plat, one inch equals 100 feet as minimum acceptable scale. 
5.  Date. 
6.  Northpoint. 
b.  Existing conditions. 
1.  An overall area map at a scale of not less than one inch equals 2,000 feet, showing the relationship of the subdivision to its surroundings such as section lines and/or major streets or collector streets, shall be provided. 
2.  Property lines of adjacent tracts of subdivided and unsubdivided land shown in relation to the tract being proposed for subdivision including those of areas across abutting roads. 
3.  Location of existing sewers, water mains, storm drains and other underground facilities within or adjacent to the tract being proposed for subdivision. 
4.  The school board or school board superintendent of the school district having jurisdiction in the area concerned shall be informed and made aware of the proposed preliminary plat by the proprietor. A letter or document from the school board or school board superintendent indicating awareness of the proprietor's intentions shall be submitted to the planning commission as part of the preliminary plat. 
c.  Proposed conditions. 
1.  Layout of streets indicating proposed street names, right-of-way widths, and connections with adjoining platted streets and also the widths and location of alleys, easements and public walkways. 
2.  Layout, numbers and dimensions of lots. 
3.  Indication of parcels of land intended to be dedicated or set aside for public use or for the use of property owners in the subdivision. 
4.  If the subdivision is proposed to be developed under the subdivision open space plan, such subdivision shall meet the requirements of section 54-61 of this article. 
(2)  Filing: 
a.  Ten copies of a valid and complete preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision, together with written application in triplicate and any other information required to be submitted under the subdivision act, shall be filed with the clerk. 
b.  Submittal with the clerk shall be at least ten days prior to the regular planning commission meeting (which meeting shall be considered as the date of filing) at which the proprietor will be scheduled to appear. Should any of the data required in this section be omitted, the clerk shall notify the proprietor of the additional data required and commission action shall be delayed until the required data is received. The commission shall act on the preliminary plat within 60 days after the date of filing unless the proprietor agrees to an extension of time in writing. 
(3)  Technical review and recommendation. The clerk shall transmit a copy of the valid and complete preliminary plat to the municipal engineer and municipal planner for their technical review and recommendation. 
(4)  Tentative approval. 
a.  Planning commission review. 
1.  The clerk shall place the preliminary plat on the next regular planning commission agenda, at which meeting the proprietor will be scheduled to appear. The planning commission shall act on the preliminary plat within 60 days after the date of filing unless the proprietor agrees, in writing, to an extension of the time required for approval by the governing body and planning commission. 
2.  It shall be the duty of the clerk to send a notice by registered or certified mail to the owners of land immediately adjoining the property to be platted of the presentment of the preliminary plat and the time and place of the meeting of the commission to consider such preliminary plat; such notice shall be sent not less than five days before the date fixed therefor. 
3.  The preliminary plat shall be reviewed by the municipal engineer as to compliance with plans for utilities and other improvements. 
4.  The municipal engineer shall notify the commission of his recommendation for either approval or rejection of the preliminary plat. 
5.  Should the commission find that the preliminary plat is not acceptable, it shall record the reason in its official minutes and forward a copy thereof together with all accompanying data to the governing body; and recommend that the governing body disapprove the preliminary plat until the objections causing disapproval have been changed to meet with the approval of the commission. 
b.  Governing body. 
1.  The governing body will not review a preliminary plat until it has received the review and recommendations of the commission. Following the receipt of such recommendations, the governing body shall consider the preliminary plat at such meeting that the matter is placed on the regularly scheduled agenda. The governing body shall take action on the preliminary plat within 90 days of the date of initial filing of the plat with the clerk, as required in subsection (2)a of this section. 
2.  Should the governing body tentatively approve the preliminary plat, it shall record its approval on the plat and return one copy to the proprietor. 
3.  Tentative approval shall not constitute final approval of the preliminary plat. 
4.  Tentative approval of the governing body shall be effective for a period of 12 months. Should the preliminary plat, in whole or in part, not be submitted for final approval within this time limit, the preliminary plat must again be submitted to the commission and governing body for approval unless an extension is applied for by the proprietor, and such request is granted in writing by the governing body, prior to its expiration. 
(5)  Review by governing body for final approval. 
a.  The proprietor shall file a valid preliminary plat with the clerk together with a certified list of all authorities required for approval in sections 112 to 119 of the Subdivision Act (MCL 560.101 et seq., MSA 26.430 et seq.), as amended. The proprietor shall also provide approved copies of preliminary plats from each of the required authorities. 
b.  The governing body shall take action on the preliminary plat within 20 days of the submission of approval of the required authorities. 
c.  If the preliminary plat conforms substantially to the plat tentatively approved by the governing body and meets all conditions laid down for tentative approval, the governing body shall give final approval to the preliminary plat. 
d.  The clerk shall promptly notify the proprietor of approval or rejection in writing; if rejected, reasons shall be given. 
e.  Final approval shall be effective for a period of two years from the date of final approval. The two-year period may be extended if applied for by the proprietor and granted by the governing body in writing, prior to its expiration. 
f.  No installation or construction of any improvements shall be made before the preliminary plat has received final approval of the governing body, engineering plans have been approved by the municipal engineer, and any deposits required under division 3 of this article have been received by the municipality. 
(Code 1975,  17-29, 17-30) 
Sec. 54-44. - Final plat. 
    The procedure for preparation and review of a final plat shall be as follows: 
(1)  Preparation: 
a.  The final plat shall comply with the provisions of the subdivision act. 
b.  The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved and it may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which the proprietor proposed to record and develop at the time; provided, however, that such portion conforms to this article. 
c.  The proprietor shall submit, as evidence of title, an abstract of title certified to date with the written opinion of an attorney-at-law thereon, or, at the option of the proprietor, a policy of title insurance for examination in order to ascertain as to whether or not the proper parties have signed the plat. 
(2)  Review: 
a.  Five mylar copies and three paper prints of the final plat shall be filed by the proprietor with the clerk and the proprietor shall deposit such sums of money as the governing body may require in this article or by other ordinances. 
b.  The final plat shall be reviewed by the municipal engineer as to compliance with the approved preliminary plat and plans for utilities and other improvements. 
c.  The municipal engineer shall notify the governing body of his recommendation for either approval or rejection of the final plat. 
d.  The governing body shall review all recommendations and take action on the final plat within 20 days of its date of filing. 
e.  Upon approval of the final plat by the governing body, the subsequent approvals shall follow the procedure set forth in the subdivision act. The three prints of the final plat shall be forwarded, two to the clerk and one to the planning commission. The five mylar copies shall be forwarded to the clerk of the county plat board. 
(Code 1975,  17-31) 
Secs. 54-45-54-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 54-56. - Purpose and intent. 
    The following design standards are intended as a guide to sound land planning and are for typical development conditions. Should there be unusual topographic or property problems, these standards may have to be modified to either greater or lesser conformance in accordance with the judgment of the planning commission and the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1975,  17-42) 
Sec. 54-57. - Streets and alleys. 
(a)  Generally. The specifications set forth in this section are by the planning commission for the width and location of all highways, streets and alleys which may be platted or accepted within the city. All such regulations are intended to be in harmony with all road right-of-way standards and policies of the city. 
(b)  Layout. The layout of proposed streets shall provide for the continuation of existing streets in surrounding areas and/or shall conform to a plan for the neighborhood approved by the planning commission in cases where topographical or other conditions preclude the continuation of existing streets. In general, such streets shall be of a width as great as that of the street so extended. Due consideration shall be given to traffic safety. Minor residential streets shall be laid out so as to discourage their use by through traffic. Due consideration shall also be given by the subdivider to the attractiveness of the street layout in order to obtain the maximum livability and amenity of the subdivision. Should a proposed subdivision border on or contain a railroad, the council may require the location of a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way at a distance suitable for the development of an appropriate use of the intervening land such as for parks in residential districts. Any intersection occurring on a street which crosses a railroad track shall not be less than 400 feet from the nearest railroad right-of-way. Greater distances may be required if it is deemed necessary for safety, approach gradients or future grade separations. 
(c)  Major streets. Where the subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed major street, the city council may, at its discretion, require the construction of marginal access streets, double frontage of lots with provisions of a screen planting contained in a no-access reservation along the rear property lines, deep lots with rear-service alleys, or other treatment which the council considers essential to adequate protection of residential lots and to separation of through and local traffic. 
(d)  Private streets and alleys. Private streets and alleys shall not be permitted, but rather all streets and alleys shall be dedicated to the public. 
(e)  Access to property. Each residential lot within a subdivision shall be provided with a satisfactory means of access. Building permits shall not be issued for the construction of buildings which do not have access onto a public street. There shall be no reserve strips controlling access to a street where the control of such is definitely placed with the council. 
(f)  Intersections. Intersecting streets shall be so laid out that the intersection angles are approximately 90 degrees, but in no case shall the angle of intersection be less than 60 degrees. Streets convening at one point shall be the least practicable number. 
(g)  Visibility. No fence, wall, structure or planting shall be erected, established or maintained on any corner lot which will obstruct the view of a driver of a vehicle approaching the intersection, except that shade trees would be permitted where all branches are not less than eight feet above the ground level, and excepting that where such branches extend over a street or alley, clear passage shall then be maintained to a height of 12 feet. Such unobstructed corner shall mean a triangular area formed by the street property lines and a line connecting them at points 30 feet from the intersection of the street lines, or, in the case of a rounded property corner, from the intersection of the street property lines extended. 
(h)  Half streets. Generally, half streets shall not be permitted where a subdivision adjoins undeveloped property, except for such major streets of over 60 feet in right-of-way width as may be recommended in the city's comprehensive plan or by the city. They shall be permitted only when the planning commission or council considers the use of a half street essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in accordance with the intent of this article and where the planning commission or council finds it practicable to require the dedication of the other half of the right-of-way when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever there already exists a dedicated and recorded half street or half alley on an adjoining plat, the other half shall be dedicated on the proposed plat to make the street or alley complete. 
(i)  Street jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall be avoided. Where streets intersect major streets, their alignment shall be continuous. 
(j)  Cul-de-sacs. Where required for the full and best utilization of the property, cul-de-sacs may be utilized. 
(k)  Dead-end streets. Dead-end streets shall be permitted only in cases where the planning commission or council is of the opinion that there is a reasonable expectation that such streets will be extended to a suitable outlet when the adjacent property is platted. If the commission or council permits the platting of the dead-end streets with the expectation of such future extension, the commission or council shall determine whether the subdivider shall provide a temporary turnaround at the closed end of the street. 
(l)  Alleys. Alleys shall not be permitted in residential areas, but may be permitted or required in commercial or industrial areas for the purpose of service access, such as for offstreet parking and loading. All such alleys shall have a minimum width of 26 feet. A diagonal cutoff shall be made at all acute and right angle intersections of two alleys sufficient to provide an inside turning radius of 30 feet. 
(m)  Street names. Street names shall not be permitted which might cause confusion with names of existing streets in or near the city. Streets that will be continuations of existing streets shall be called by the same names of such existing streets. All names shall be approved by the city council. 
(n)  Building lines and setback lines. Building and setback lines shall conform to the requirements of the city zoning ordinance. 
(o)  Right-of-way widths. Street right-of-way widths shall conform to at least the following minimum requirements: 
Street type Minimum right-of-way 
(feet) (1) Major streets ..... 100 (2) Collector streets .....  86 (3) Industrial service streets .....  60 (4) Local residential .....  60 (5) Turnaround (loop) street ..... 120 (6) Alley .....  26 (7) Cul-de-sac streets, turnarounds: a. Industrial ..... 110 b. Residential and others .....  80  
Maximum length for residential cul-de-sac streets shall generally be 500 feet. Maximum length for industrial and other cul-de-sac streets may exceed 500 feet subject to the approval of the city council. 
(p)  Horizontal alignment. The centerline of pavement shall coincide with the centerline right-of-way, except for irregular right-of-way widths. 
(q)  Street grades. For adequate drainage, the minimum street grades shall not be less than 0.5 percent. The maximum street grade shall be 5.0 percent, except that the city council may make an exception to this standard on the recommendation of the engineer. 
(r)  Street curvature. The minimum horizontal centerline radii of curved local streets shall be 200 feet. Greater radii may be required for principal streets of a 60-foot right-of-way. Greater tangents shall be required on streets of greater right-of-way. 
(s)  Radii at intersections. Minimum pavement radii at intersections shall be 40 feet at intersections of county primary roads, 25 feet at intersections with major streets of over a 60-foot right-of-way, and 20 feet on local streets. 
(t)  Surface drainage. 
(1)  The preferred plan for yard drainage shall provide for drainage from the front of the lot to the rear of the lot with a minimum grade of one percent and a maximum grade of three percent. Front yard drainage may be authorized by the city superintendent. 
(2)  If it is found to be essential to the economical development of substantial portions of a project, the easement at the rear of the lot may be below the building grade. In this event the grade shall be not less than one percent nor more than three percent and the grade from the house to the street shall be not less than one percent with the building grade being not less than 12 inches above the street grade. 
(3)  Where low easements are essential to the economical development of major portions of the project, the longitudinal grade of such easements shall not be less than four-tenths of one percent and the length of such longitudinal easements shall not exceed 500 feet of continuous drainage, with no more than 100 feet of such distance being upstream from an angle point in the easement. 
(4)  Where required by the city engineer, there shall be provided a four-inch drain with the drain tile being laid in a trench being backfilled with pea gravel or approved bank-run gravel, the depth and outlet for such tile being subject to city approval. 
(u)  Access to streets across ditches. Subdividers shall provide access to all proposed streets across watercourses or ditches in a standard manner approved by the county road commission and the county drain commission. 
(Code 1975,  17-43) 
Sec. 54-58. - Utility and other easements. 
(a)  The subdivider shall contact each public utility involved for preferred locations of easements. Utility easements shall be located preferably along rear property lines, but may be located alongside lot lines and front lot lines if necessary. Utility easements shall not be less than 12 feet in total width, with six feet located on each side of the property line. Utility easements six feet wide are permissible along rear property lines, if such rear property lines abut unplatted land. 
(b)  Drainage easements shall be provided which conform substantially with the lines of any natural watercourses, drainage ditches, channels or streams. Such easements shall be of adequate width for the particular conditions of the site. The planning commission or the city council may consider and impose requirements necessary to provide for rear yard swales, a minimum width eight feet (four feet either side of property line) to be fully constructed by the subdivider to finished slopes and ground elevations (within 0.2 feet) complete with ground cover prior to final approval. The swale, if required, shall be maintained in a permanent drainage easement and is not subject to any alterations once approved. The planning commission or the city council may, if it considers such requirement necessary to the proper development of the subdivision and the circulation of local traffic, require that the drain, if within a public right-of-way, will be tiled and enclosed. 
(Code 1975,  17-44; Ord. No. 1991-01,  1, 1-21-91) 
Sec. 54-59. - Lots. 
(a)  Generally. The size, shape and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated. Lots shall be of such size as to permit a variety of house types, to provide side yards for desirable access, light, air, privacy and safety from fire hazards, to provide for setbacks from the street line and to allow sufficient space for household purposes. 
(b)  Access. All lots shall abut by their full frontage on a properly dedicated street. Lots, other than corner lots, normally should not be permitted to front onto two streets. 
(c)  Width. The minimum width of any lot shall be 60 feet, except that greater widths may be required in the zoning ordinance. Where desirable, to plat wedge-shaped lots so as to best utilize a parcel of land, the required lot width shall be measured at the front building line, from and parallel to the front property line, when the front lot line is narrower than the rear lot line. When the rear lot line is narrower than the front line, the width shall be measured at the rear building line and be parallel to the rear property line. 
(d)  Repealed. 
(e)  Corner lots. Corner lots shall be provided extra width sufficient to permit the maintenance of building setback lines on both the front and side street lines in order to protect similar setbacks on both the front and side streets which exist or are planned. Where lots have side yards abutting upon a street, on the same side of which other residential lots front in the same block, the lots shall be of such width to permit a side yard setback on the street equivalent to the required front yard setback of the lots fronting on such street. 
(f)  Side lot lines. Side property lines of lots shall generally be perpendicular to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines, unless a variation from this rule will give a better lot plat. Property lines on sides and rear of lots should be straight. 
(g)  Area. The width and depth of lots shall be such that minimum lot areas will be in accordance with the zoning ordinance. 
(h)  Business or commercial lots. No lot or parcel classified as business or commercial shall be platted that is less than 60 feet in width. The area of such lot or parcel shall be sufficient in size so as to provide sufficient area for offstreet parking and loading in accordance with the requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1975,  17-45; Ord. No. 2005-03,  1, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 54-60. - Blocks. 
(a)  Generally. The size and shape of blocks shall be appropriate for the type of lots and land use proposed. Blocks shall be designed so as to permit good lot orientation, safe street design and economical use of the land. 
(b)  Length. Length of blocks between intersecting streets shall normally be from 400 to 800 feet. This form shall be altered only where the topography of the land makes it advisable to do so in order to protect the public safety and convenience, and in no event shall blocks be less than 300 feet in length. Where blocks exceed 800 feet in length, an easement up to 20 feet in width may be required by the planning commission or council near the center of each block for a pedestrian walkway. 
(c)  Nonresidential blocks. Blocks intended for purposes other than residential shall be especially designed for such purposes and shall have adequate provision for offstreet parking and loading in accordance with the requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1975,  17-46) 
Sec. 54-61. - Open spaces. 
    In the design of the plat, thorough and equitable consideration shall be given by the subdivider and the planning commission to the provision of suitable sites for recreational, school and other public purposes. The location of these areas should conform to the objectives of the comprehensive plan and shall not be unreasonable in area in relation to the land being subdivided and the prospective uses of such land. 
(Code 1975,  17-47) 
Sec. 54-62. - Uses. 
(a)  Control. No property shall be subdivided for residential use if such is considered unsuitable for building purposes by the planning commission or council. 
(b)  Restrictions. Whenever property is subdivided with the intention that it shall have a use more restrictive than that designated in the zoning ordinance, such use shall be stated in an application for an amendment to the zoning ordinance or in a separate statement filed with the planning commission. Conformance with the objectives of the comprehensive plan shall be required so as to ensure general uniformity of land uses within blocks and neighborhoods. 
(c)  Conformance with zoning ordinance. Property use and area restrictions must be in accordance with the zoning ordinance. 
(d)  Business and commercial lots. Business or commercial lots, when platted, shall bear a reasonable relation in number to the probable number of families constituting the purchasing power of the surrounding tributary area. The planning commission shall recommend the location of business and commercial lots in accordance with the comprehensive development plan and the zoning ordinance. 
(e)  Land subject to flooding. Any areas of land within the proposed subdivision which are subject to flooding or inundation by stormwater shall be clearly shown on the final plat. Such land shall not be platted for residential occupancy nor for such other purposes or uses as may increase damage to health, life or property, or unduly aggravate the flood hazard. All subdivision proposals for land located in any of the flood hazard areas of the city as determined by article 16-5 of the zoning ordinance shall be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage and shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to minimize flood damage. All such proposals shall provide for adequate drainage to reduce or eliminate exposure to flood hazards, and base flood elevation data shall be provided for all such proposals for development which are greater than the lesser of 50 lots or five acres. 
(Code 1975,  17-48) 
Sec. 54-63. - Utilities and improvements. 
    In order to provide healthful, clean and desirable living conditions, the subdivider shall be entirely responsible for installing the following site improvements, or shall furnish to the city a surety bond executed by a reputable surety company authorized to do business in the state, sufficient to permit the completion of all contemplated improvements, before a plat shall be accepted by the city: 
(1)  Storm drainage. All subdivisions shall have storm drains which shall be approved by the municipal engineer and governing body, and which shall conform to the following standards: 
a.  Storm sewers shall be provided in such a manner that each lot, outlot or parcel is serviced by a storm sewer. An outlet shall be provided for each lot, outlot or parcel for the purpose of connecting the sump pump discharge of the storm and ground water collected in footing drains. 
b.  The storm sewer described in this subsection (1) of this section may be the public storm sewer located in the street right-of-way or a private storm sewer located in an easement at the rear of a lot, outlot, or parcel or combination of the same. A storm sewer located in an easement at the rear of a lot, outlot, or parcel or combination of the same will not be maintained, repaired or replaced by the municipality or government agency, nor shall the municipality or government agency have any responsibility for such storm sewer, except for such duties as may be imposed upon the municipality or government agency by statute, ordinance or regulation. 
c.  If repairs are needed to any portion of the storm drainage system not located in the street right-of-way as determined by the city, and if the benefiting lot owners do not make the repairs, the city may, at its sole discretion, proceed to make the repairs itself or contract for the repairs, and the benefiting lot owners shall be responsible for and shall pay their proportionate share of the cost for such repairs. If the city shall make such repairs or cause such repairs to be made as provided in this subsection, the city shall bill all benefiting lot owners for their proportionate share of the costs of such repairs and all benefiting lot owners shall pay their proportionate share of the costs of such repairs to the city within 30 days after the date of billing. It is further provided that if a benefiting lot owner shall fail or refuse to pay his proportionate share of the costs of repairs as determined by the city and as provided in this subsection, such unpaid amount shall become a lien upon the subject property of the nonpaying lot owner and such lien may be collected by the city in the same manner as taxes are collected by the city, or in any other manner permitted by law. 
d.  A sump pump outlet must be provided to each lot (lot line or easement line) connected by an approved method to a storm sewer, rear yard underdrain, or storm sewer structure immediately adjacent to the lot. The sump pump outlet pipe shall be a type intended for underground use and shall have a minimum crushing strength of 1,000 pounds per linear foot. Minimum grade is 1.0 percent. 
e.  Rear yard drainage is required in all residential subdivisions, except where otherwise authorized. 
1.  All catchbasins, rear yard underdrains, swales and sump pumps shall drain to the storm sewer described in subsections (1)a through c of this section. 
2.  Rear yard swales shall be no longer than 500 feet before being intercepted by a standard catchbasin and shall have a minimum grade of 1.0 percent. 
3.  Rear yard swales more than 120 feet in length must not be graded straight down to a street without being intercepted by a standard catchbasin and a low point shall be established. 
4.  Side yard swales between houses must be a minimum of 0.5 foot lower than the lower adjacent house grade. 
5.  Where topography prevents rear yard drainage from being practical, rear to front drainage may drain only the specific lot in question. Other bordering lots are not to drain across this lot. Lots with rear to front drainage must have swales around the house with a swale grade of 2.0 percent or more. 
(2)  Sanitary sewerage system. Where provided, the location and design of all trunkline and lateral sanitary sewers and any other necessary appurtenances such as pumping stations shall first be approved by the municipal engineer and all applicable reviewing agencies, and all work shall be carried out under the supervision of the engineer. 
(3)  Water systems. The location and design of water mains with house connections, the installation of fire hydrants, and any other necessary appurtenances shall first be approved by the municipal engineer and all applicable reviewing agencies as to suitability and all work shall be carried out under the direction of the city engineer. 
(4)  Street construction. All streets shall conform to the following criteria which shall be considered as minimum standards: 
a.  Commercial and industrial streets. Commercial and industrial streets shall be of concrete surface and integral curb. The design standard relating to width and depth shall be reviewed by the municipal engineer and approved by the city council. 
b.  Residential streets. Pavement width of residential streets shall not be less than 28 feet from back of curb to back of curb. Greater widths may be required and therefore are subject to review by the municipal engineer and approval by the city council. All work shall be carried out under the direction of the city engineer. The following types of construction may be reviewed and approved as provided in this section: 
1.  Deep strength asphalt pavement with concrete curb and gutter: Minimum thickness of the deep strength asphalt shall be six inches in street construction of this type. Such pavement shall be constructed on a granular base, which requirement shall depend upon the type of soil common to the area where the pavement is located. 
2.  Asphalt on compacted granular base: Minimum thickness of the asphalt shall be 21/2 inches in street construction of this type. Such pavement shall be constructed on a compacted, aggregate base which shall be not less than eight inches thick. 
3.  Concrete with integral curb and gutter: Minimum thickness of street construction of this type shall be not less than six inches. Such pavement shall be constructed on a granular base, the requirements for which shall depend upon the nature of the base, soil conditions and related engineering considerations. 
c.  Parking. In order to provide adequate traffic flow and emergency vehicle ingress and egress, the subdivider shall consider the following pavement widths and onstreet parking restrictions: 
Curbed streets Face-to-face 
of curb (feet) No parking ..... 27 Parallel parking, one side ..... 31 Parallel parking, both sides ..... 39  
If parking is to be permitted on one side the restriction shall apply as follows: 
1.  Streets of a north-south direction shall have no parking permitted on the west side of the street. 
2.  Streets of an east-west direction shall have no parking permitted on the south side of the street. 
(5)  Sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be required on at least one side of each street subject to council approval and conform to the following standards: 
a.  Minimum width shall be four feet. 
b.  Walks shall be located no closer than one foot from property lines. 
c.  Construction: 
1.  Four-inch clear sand base. 
2.  Four-inch-thick concrete with six-inch thickness at driveway crossings. 
3.  Concrete shall be no less than four parts sand or gravel and one part cement. 
(6)  Utilities; requirements for underground wiring. All local distribution lines including telephone, electric, television, and other similar services distributed by wire or cable shall be placed entirely underground throughout the area subdivided, except for main supply and perimeter feed distribution lines which serve areas outside the subdivided area, and except for surface facilities related to underground service, such as above ground closures or terminals. Such wires, conduits or cables shall be placed within private easements provided to such service companies by the proprietor or within dedicated public ways. 
Overhead local distribution lines within such subdivided area may be permitted upon written recommendation from the planning commission and approval of the city council at the time of final plat approval where it is determined that underground lines would not be consistent with the general welfare, health, safety, plat design and character of the subdivision. 
All such facilities shall be constructed in accordance with standards of construction approved by the state public service commission. All drainage and underground utility installations which traverse privately owned property shall be protected by easements granted by the proprietor. 
(Code 1975,  17-49; Ord. No. 1991-02,  1, 2-4-91; Ord. No. 1996-17,  1, 12-2-96) 
Sec. 54-64. - Protection of natural features. 
    Due regard shall be shown for all natural features, such as large trees, exceptionally fine groves of trees, watercourses, scenic points, historic spots, and similar community assets, which, if preserved, will add attractiveness and value to the subdivision. 
(Code 1975,  17-50) 
Sec. 54-65. - Application of subdivision act. 
  
Chapters 55-57 - RESERVED 
Chapter 58 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
